div.p: THE FASHIONABLE LOVER; A COMEDY: As it is acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: Printed for W. GRIFFIN, at GARRICK's HEAD, in Catharine-Street, Strand. MDCCLXXII.

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: I COMMIT this Comedy to the preſs with all poſſible gratitude to the Public for the reception it has met: I cannot flatter myſelf that the ſame applauſe will follow it to the cloſet; for as it owed much to an excellent repreſentation, I have neither on this, nor any preceding occaſion, conſidered myſelf otherwiſe than as a ſharer only with the Managers and Performers, who have diſtinguiſhed themſelves in the exhibition of my trifling productions. But it is not on the ſcore of ſpectacle only that I am obliged to Mr. Garrick; I am both in the inſtance of this Comedy, and in that of the Weſt Indian, materially indebted to his judgment, and owe the good effect of many incidents in both to his ſuggeſtion and advice: the correction of a real critic is as different from that of a pretender, as the operation of a ſurgeon from the ſtab of an aſſaſſin.

The Comedy, now ſubmitted to the reader, is deſign'd as an attempt upon his heart, and as ſuch proceeds with little deviation from mine; if it ſhould be thought therefore, that I have meant well, the charge of having executed indifferently I ſhall patiently ſubmit to: I have on this occaſion, (as on the two preceding ones) wholly reſted my performance upon ſuch poor abilities, as I am maſter of; I am not conſcious of having drawn any particular aſſiſtance, either in reſpect of character or deſign, from the productions of others; altho' I am far from preſuming to ſay or think, that I have ever exhibited any character purely original: The level manners of a poliſh'd country, like this, do not ſupply much matter for the comic muſe, which delights in variety and extravagance; whereever therefore I have made any attempts at novelty, I have found myſelf obliged either to dive into the lower claſs of men, or betake myſelf to the out-ſkirts of the empire; the center is too equal and refined for ſuch purpoſes.

head.hi: SPOKEN BY MR. WESTON, In the Character of a Printer's Devil.

lg.l: I AM a devil, ſo pleaſe you—and muſt hoof
Up to the poet yonder with this proof:
I'd read it to you, but, in faith, 'tis odds
For one poor Devil to face ſo many Gods.
A ready imp I am, who kindly greets
Young authors with their firſt exploits in ſheets;
While the Preſs groans, in place of dry-nurſe ſtands,
And takes the bantling from the midwife's hands.
If any author of prolific brains,
In this good company, feels labour-pains;
If any gentle poet, big with rhime,
Has run his reck'ning out and gone his time;
If any critic, pregnant with ill-nature,
Cries out to be deliver'd of his ſatire;
Know ſuch that at our Hoſpital of Muſes
He may lye in, in private, if he chuſes;
We've ſingle lodgings there for ſecret ſinners,
With good encouragement for young beginners.
Here's one now that is free enough in reaſon;
This bard breeds regularly once a ſeaſon;
Three of a ſort, of homely form and feature,
The plain coarſe progeny of humble nature;
Home-bred and born; no ſtrangers he diſplays,
Nor tortures free-born limbs in ſtiff French ſtays:
Two you have rear'd; but between you and me,
This youngeſt is the fav'rite of the three.
Nine tedious months he bore this babe about,
Let it in charity live nine nights out;
Stay but his month up; give ſome little law;
'Tis cowardly to attack him in the ſtraw.
Dear Gentlemen Correctors, be more civil;
Kind courteous Sirs, take counſel of the Devil;
Stop your abuſe, for while your readers ſee
Such malice, they impute your works to me;
Thus, while you gather no one ſprig of fame,
Your poor unhappy friend is put to ſhame:
Faith, Sirs, you ſhou'd have ſome conſideration,
When ev'n the Devil pleads againſt Damnation.
LADIES, your country's ornament and pride,
Ye, whom the nuptial deity has tied
In ſilken ſetters, will ye not impart
For pity's ſake ſome portion of your art
To a mere novice, and preſcribe ſome plan
How you would have me live with my good man?
Tell me, if I ſhould give each paſſing hour
To love of pleaſure or to love of power;
If with the fatal thirſt of deſperate play
I ſhou'd turn day to night and night to day;
Had I the faculty to make a prize
Of each pert animal that meets my eyes,
Say are theſe objects worth my ſerious aim;
Do they give happineſs or health or fame?
Are hecatombs of lovers hearts of force
To deprecate the demons of divorce?
Speak, my adviſers, ſhall I gain the plan
Of that bold club, which gives the law to man,
At their own weapons that proud ſex defies
And ſets up a new female paradiſe?
Lights for the ladies! Hark, the bar-bells ſound!
Show to the club-room—See the glaſs goes round—
Hail, happy meeting of the good and fair,
Soft relaxation from domeſtic care,
Where virgin minds are early train'd to loo,
And all Newmarket opens to the view.
In theſe gay ſcenes ſhall I affect to move,
Or paſs my hours in dull domeſtic love?
Shall I to rural ſolitudes deſcend
With Tyrrel my protector, guardian, friend,
Or to the rich Pantheon's round repair,
And blaze the brighteſt heathen-goddeſs there?
Where ſhall I ſix? Determine ye who know,
Shall I renounce my huſband, or Soho?
With eyes half-open'd and an aking head
And ev'n the artificial roſes dead,
When to my toilette's morning taſk reſign'd,
What viſitations then may ſeize my mind!
Save me, juſt Heaven, from ſuch a painful life,
And make me an unfaſhionable wife!

div.head: ACT I. SCENE I.
div.stage: A hall in LORD ABBERVILLE's houſe, with a ſtair-caſe ſeen through an arch. Several domeſtics waiting in rich liveries. Flouriſh of French horns.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: HOOT! fellows, haud your honds: pack up your damn'd clarinets, and gang your gait, for a pair of lubberly minſtrels, as you are. An you cou'd hondle the bagpipe inſtead, I wou'd na' ſay you nay: ah! 'tis an auncient inſtrument of great melody, and has whaſtled many a braw lad to his grave; but your holidays horns there are fit only to play to a drunken city-barge on a ſwan-hopping party up the Thames.

sp.speaker: La Jeu.
sp.p: Fedon, Monſieur Colin, for why you have ſend away the horns? It is very much the ton in this country for the fine gentlemens to have the horns: upon my vord, my Lord this day give grand entertainment to very grand company; tous les maccaroni below ſtairs, et toute la coterie above. Hark, who vait dere? My Lord ring his bell.—Voi la, Monſieur Colin, dere is all the company going to the tea-room.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p:
Now the de'el burſt the weams of you all together, ſay I, for a pack of locuſts; a cow in a clover field has more moderation than the beſt among you:
had my lord Abberville the wealth of Glaſgow, you'd ſwallow it all down before you gee'd over.—Crom, crom.

sp.speaker: La Jeu.
sp.p: Vat is dat crom, crom? We do not know in France vat is dat crom, crom. But vat you ſay to the dinner? Upon my vord Monſieur the cook, make as fine diſpoſitions for the table, as the Grand Condé did for the battle: ma foi, he merit to have his ſtatue raiſed en crocan, in the center of his own performance.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Rais'd on a gibbet in the center of Hounſlow Heath; that's what he merits.

sp.speaker: La Jeu.
sp.p: Ah, barbare! Here come my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Colin, ſee that covers are laid for four-and-twenty, and ſupper ſerved at twelve in the great eating-parlour.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ecod, my Lord, had you ken'd the meſs of cakes and ſweeties that was honded up amongſt 'em juſt now, you wou'd na' think there cou'd be muckle need of ſupper this night.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What, fellow, wou'd you have me ſtarve my gueſts?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Troth, an you don't, they'll go nigh to ſtarve you.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Let me hear no more of this, Colin Macleod; I took you for my ſervant, not for my adviſer.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Right, my Lord, you did; but if by adviſing I can ſerve you, where's the breach of duty in that?

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What a Highland ſavage it is.—My father indeed made uſe of him to pay the ſervants wages, and poſt the tradeſmen's accounts; as I never do either, I wiſh ſomebody elſe had him that does.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: "Is this a dinner, this a genial room?
"This is a temple and a hecatomb."

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What quoting, Mortimer? and ſatire too?—I thought you need not go abroad for that.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: True; therefore, I'm returning home.—Good night to you.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What, on the wing ſo ſoon! With ſo much company can my philoſopher want food to feaſt his ſpleen upon?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Food! I revolt againſt the name; no Bramin cou'd abominate your fleſhly meal more than I do, why Hirtius and Apicius would have bluſh'd for it: Marc Antony, who roaſted eight whole boars for ſupper, never maſſacred more at a meal than you have done.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: A truce, good cynick: pr'ythee now get thee up ſtairs, and take my place; the ladies will be glad of you at cards.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Me at cards! me at a quadrille-table; pent in with fuzzing dowagers, goſſiping old maids and yellow admirals; 'ſdeath, my Lord Abberville, you muſt excuſe me

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Out on thee, unconformable being, thou art a traitor to ſociety.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do you call that ſociety?

sp.speaker: L. Abb
sp.p: Yes, but not my ſociety; none ſuch as you deſcribe will be found here; my circle, Mr. Mortimer, is form'd by people of the firſt faſhion and ſpirit in this country.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Faſhion and ſpirit! Yes, their country's like to ſuffer by their faſhion more than 'twill ever profit by their ſpirit.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Come, come, your temper is too ſour.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: And your's too ſweet: a mawkiſh lump of manna; ſugar in the mouth, but phyſic to the bowels.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Mr. Mortimer, you was my father's executor; I did not know your office extended any further.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: No; when I gave a clear eſtate into your hands, I clear'd myſelf of an unwelcome office: I was, indeed, your father's executor; the gentlemen of faſhion and ſpirit will be your lordſhip's.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Pooh! you've been black-ball'd at ſome paltry port-drinking club; and ſet up for a man of wit and ridicule.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Not I, believe me: your companions are too dull to laugh at, and too vicious to expoſe.—There ſtands a ſample of your choice.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Who, Doctor Druid? Where's the harm in him?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
Where is the merit?—What one quality does that old piece of pedantry poſſeſs to fit him for the liberal office of travelling preceptor to a man of rank? You know, my Lord, I recommended you a friend as fit to form your
manners as your morals; but he was a reſtraint; and, in his ſtead, you took that Welchman, that buffoon, that antiquarian forſooth, who looks as if you had rak'd him out of the cinders of Mount Veſuvius.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: And ſo I did: but pr'ythee, Mortimer, don't run away; I long to have you meet.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You muſt excuſe me.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Nay, I muſt have you better friends.—Come hither, Doctor, hark'e—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Another time, at preſent, I am in no humour to ſtay the diſcuſſion of a cockle-ſhell, or the diſſection of a butterfly • s wing.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Putterflies! putterflies in your teeth, Mr. Mortimer. What is the ſurly-poots prabbling about? Cot give her coot luck; will the man never leave off his flings, and his fleers, and his fegaries; packpiting his petters?—Coot, my Lord, let me call him back, and have a little tiſputes and tiſputations with him, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Hang him, tedious rogue, let him go.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Tedious! ay, in coot truth is he, as tedious as a Lapland winter, and as melancholy too; his crochets, and his humours damp all mirth and merriment, as a wet blanket does a fire: he is the very night-mare of ſociety.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Nay, he talks well ſometimes.

sp.speaker: D. Druid.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis pig ſound, and little wit; like a loud pell, to a pad dinner.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Patience, good Doctor, patience! another time you ſhall have your revenge, at preſent you muſt lay down your wrath, and take up your attention.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Iv'e done, my Lord, Iv'e done: laugh at my putterflies indeed! if he was as pig and as pold as King Gryffyn, Doctor Druid wou'd make free to whiſper an oord or two in his ear.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Peace, cholerick King of the mountains, peace.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Iv'e done, my Lord, I ſay Iv'e done.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: If you have done, let me begin. You muſt know then, I expect my city madam from Fiſh-ſtreet Hill.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the rich pig-pellied fellow's daughter, young Madam Pridgemore, my Lady Apperville, that is to be, pleſs her, and ſave her, and make her a coot wife, ſay I.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Pr'ythee, good Doctor, don't put a man in mind of his misfortunes: I tell you, ſhe is coming here by appointment, with old Bridgemore and her mother; 'tis an execrable groupe, and as I mean to make all things as eaſy to me as I can, I'm going out to avoid being troubled with their impertinence.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Going out, my Lord, with your houſe full of company?

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Oh! that's no objection, none in the leaſt, faſhion reconciles all thoſe ſcruples: to conſult your own eaſe in all things is the very firſt article in the recipe for good breeding; when every man looks after himſelf, no one can complain of neglect; but as theſe maxims may not be orthodox on the eaſtern ſide of Temple-bar, you muſt ſtand Gentleman Uſher in this ſpot; put your beſt face upon the matter, and marſhal my citizens into the aſſembly room, with as much ceremony, as if they came up with an addreſs from the whole company of Cordwainers.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Out on it, youv'e ſome teviliſh oomans in the wind, for when the tice are rattling above, there's nothing but teath, or the tevil, cou'd keep you below.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Youv'e gueſt it; ſuch a divine, delicious little devil, lurks in my heart; Glendower himſelf cou'd not exorciſe her: I am poſſeſt, and from the hour I ſaw her by ſurprize, I have been plotting methods how to meet her; a lucky opening offers, the mine is laid, and Bridgemore's viſit is the ſignal for ſpringing it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Pridgemore's! how ſo?

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Why, 'tis with him ſhe lives; what elſe cou'd make it difficult, and what but difficulty, cou'd make me purſue it? They prudently enough wou'd have conceal'd her from me, for who can think of any other, when Miſs Aubrey is in ſight?—But hark! they're come; I muſt eſcape—Now, love and fortune, ſtand my friends!

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Pleſs us, what haſtes and hurries he is in, and all for ſome young huſſey—Ah! he'll never have a proper reliſh for the venerable antique: I never ſhall bring down his mercury, to touch the proper freezing point, which that of a true virtuoſo ought to ſtand at: ſometimes indeed he will contemplate a beautiful ſtatue, as if it was a ooman; I never cou'd perſuade him to look upon a beautiful ooman, as if ſhe was a ſtatue.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Doctor, I kiſs your hands; I kiſs your hands, good Doctor.—How theſe nobles live! Zooks, what a ſwinging chamber!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Bridgemore, ſure you think yourſelf in Leatherſeller's hall.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray recollect yourſelf, Pappa; indeed this is not Fiſh ſtreet Hill.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I wiſh it was: I'd ſoon unhouſe this trumpery: I'd ſoon furniſh it with better goods: why this profuſion, child, will turn your brain.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Law, how you ſtand and ſtare at things; ſtopping in the hall to count the ſervants, gaping at the luſtre there, as if you'd ſwallow it.—I ſuppoſe our daughter, when ſhe's a woman of quality, will behave as other women of quality do.—Lucinda, this is Doctor Druid, Lord Abberville's travelling tutor, a gentleman of a very antient family in North Wales.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So it ſhould ſeem, if he's the repreſentative of it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Without flattery, Mrs. Bridgemore, Miſs has very much the behaviours of an ooman of quality already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Come Sir, we'll join the company, Lord Abberville will think us late.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid
sp.p: Yes truly, he's impatient for your coming, but you ſhall find him not at home.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: How; not at home?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A mighty proof of his impatience, truly.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Why, 'twas ſome plaguy buſineſs took him out, but we'll diſpatch it out of hand, and wait upon you quickly.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, buſineſs, buſineſs muſt be done.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: I thought my Lord had been a man of faſhion, not of buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ſo he is; a man of the firſt faſhion; you cannot have a freſher ſample: the worſt gallant in nature is your maccaroni; with the airs of a coquette you meet the manners of a clown: fear keeps him in ſome awe before the men, but not one ſpark of paſſion has he at heart, to remind him of the ladies.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Well, we muſt make our curtſies above ſtairs—our card was from Lady Caroline; I ſuppoſe ſhe is not from home, as well as her brother.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid,
sp.p: Who waits there? ſhow the ladies up.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Ay, ay, go up, and ſhow your cloaths, I'll chat with Dr. Druid here below.
I love to talk with men that know the world; they tell me, Sir, you've travelled it all over.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Into a pretty many parts of it.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, and what ſay you, Sir? you're glad to be at home; nothing I warrant like old England. Ah I what's France, and Spain, and Burgundy, and Flanders? no, old England for my money; 'tis worth all the world beſides.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Your pelly ſays as much; 'twill fill the pot, but ſtarve the prain; 'tis full of corn, and ſheep, and villages, and people: England, to the reſt of the oorld, is like a flower-garden to a foreſt.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, but the people, Sir, what ſay you to the people?

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Nothing: I never meddle with the human ſpecies; man, living man, is no object of my curioſity, nor ooman neither; at leaſt, Mr. Pridgemore, till ſhe ſhall be made a mummies of.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I underſtand you; you ſpeak in the way of trade: money's your object.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Money and trade! I ſcorn 'em both; the beaten track of commerce I diſdain to follow: I've traced the Oxus, and the Ton; traverſed the Riphaean Mountains, and pierced into the inmoſt Teſarts of Kalmuc Tartary—follow trade indeed! no; Iv'e followed the ravages of Kouli Chan with rapturous delight: there is the land of wonders; finely depopulated; gloriouſly laid waſte; fields without a hoof to tread 'em, fruits without a hand to gather 'em; with ſuch a catalogue of pats, peetles, ſerpents, ſcorpions, caterpillars, toads—oh! tis a recreating contemplation, to a philoſophic mind!

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Out on 'em, filthy vermin, I hope you left 'em where you found 'em.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: No, to my honour be it ſpoken, I have imported above fifty different ſorts of mortal poiſons into my native country.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Lackaday, there's people enough at home can poiſon their native country. (Mrs. BRIDGEMORE and LUCINDA enter) So, Ladies, have you finiſhed your viſit already?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridg.
sp.p: We've have made our curtſies and come away.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Marry, the fates and the fortunes forbid that you ſhould go, till my Lord comes back.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why not? if my Lord treats me already with the freedom of a huſband, ſhoudn't I begin to practiſe the indifference of a Wife?

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Well, but the ſupper, Mr. Pridgemore; you a citizen, and leave the ſupper?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Your fifty mortal poiſons have given me my ſupper: ſcorpions, and bats, and toads—come let's be gone.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Wou'd, they were in your pelly!

div.stage: MISS AUBREY and TYRREL, and a maid-ſervant with lights.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: How I am watch'd in this houſe you well know, Mr. Tyrrel; therefore you muſt not ſtay: what you have done and ſuffer'd for my ſake I never can forget; and 'tis with joy I ſee you now, at laſt, ſurmount your difficulties by the recovery of Lord Courtland: may your life never be again expoſed on my account!

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I glory in protecting you; when he, or any other rake, repeats the like offence, I ſhall repeat the like correction. I am now going to my uncle Mortimer, who does not know that I am in town. Life is not life without thee; never will I quit his feet, till I've obtain'd his voice for our alliance.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Alas! What hope of that from Mr. Mortimer, whoſe rugged nature knows no happineſs itſelf, nor feels complacency in that of others?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: When you know Mr. Mortimer you'll find how totally the world miſtakes him. Farewel, my dear Auguſta; back'd with thy virtuous wiſhes, how can I fail to proſper?
sp.stage: (He goes out, and ſhe enters an inner apartment. The maid-ſervant immediately introduces LORD ABBERVILLE.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: All's ſafe; follow me, my Lord; ſhe is in her bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Where; where?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p:
There; where you ſee the light through the
glaſs-door. If I thought you had any wicked deſigns in your head, I wou'dn't have brought you here for the world; I ſhou'd be murder'd if the family were to know it: for pity's ſake, my Lord, never betray me.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Go, get you gone; never talk of treaſon, my thoughts are full of love. (The maid-ſervant goes out.) Firſt I'll ſecure the door: 'twill not be amiſs to bar this retreat. (Locks the door, and advances to the glaſs-door.) Ay, there ſhe is!—How penſive is that poſture!—Muſing on her condition; which, in truth, is melancholy enough; an humble couſin to a vulgar tyrant.—'Sdeath, ſhe cannot chuſe but jump at my propoſals.—See, ſhe weeps.—I'm glad on't—Grief diſpoſes to compliance—'Tis the very moment to aſſail her.
sp.stage: (She comes to the door, with the candle in her hand; ſeeing LORD ABBERVILLE, ſtarts.)

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Who's there; who's at the door? Ah!—

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh; your ſcreams will rouſe the houſe.—'Tis I, Miſs Aubrey—'tis Lord Abberville.—Give me your hand.—Nay, be compoſed.—Let me ſet down the candle: you are ſafe.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Safe, my Lord! Yes, I'm ſafe; but you are miſtaken; Miſs Bridgemore's not at home; or, if ſhe was, this is no place to meet her in.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: I'm glad of that; bleſs'd in Miſs Aubrey's company, I wiſh no interruption from Miſs Bridgemore.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I ſhould be loath to think ſo; an avowal of baſeneſs to one woman, ſhould never be taken as flattery by another: in ſhort, my Lord, I muſt intreat you to let the ſervants ſhow you to ſome fitter apartment. I am here in a very particular ſituation, and have the ſtrongeſt reaſons for what I requeſt.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: I gueſs your reaſons, but cannot admit them. I love you, Madam; let that declaration be my excuſe.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Nay, now your frolick has the air of inſult, and I inſiſt upon your leaving me. (A rapping is heard at the door.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who's within there?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Hark, hark, Miſs Bridgemore, as I live.—Come in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come in! why you have lock'd the door.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Lock'd! is it lock'd?—for ſhame, for ſhame! thus am I ſacrific'd to your ungenerous deſigns:—ſhe muſt come in.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Stay, ſtay; ſhe muſt not find me here; there's one retreat; your chamber; lock me in there: I may ſtill eſcape.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What are you about, Miſs Aubrey? Let me in.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Where ſhall I turn myſelf? You've ruined all: if you're diſcovered, I ſhall never gain belief.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Be adviſed then: we have only this chance left (goes to the bed-room door.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Miſs Aubrey, if you don't let me in immediately, I ſhall call up my mamma; ſo pray unlock the door.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I ſcarce know what I do (after locking Lord Abberville in, opens the outward door.) There, Madam, you're obeyed.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, ſurely, you affect extraordinary privacy. It ſeems you've had your Tyrrel in our abſence.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Tyrrel has been here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Humph! you're in mighty ſpirits.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: No, Madam; my poor ſpirits ſuit my poor condition: you, I hope, are rich in every ſenſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She's happy I can ſee, though ſhe attempts to hide it: I can't bear her.—Pray, Miſs Aubrey, what are your deſigns—to ruin this young man?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Madam!—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Can you now in your heart ſuppoſe that Mortimer will let his nephew marry you? Depend upon't (I tell you as your friend) as ſoon as that old cynic hears of it (which I have taken care he ſhall) your hopes are cruſhed at once.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: When were they otherwiſe?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I don't know what to make of her—ſhe ſeems confus'd—her eyes wander ſtrangely: watching the bedroom door—what is it ſhe looks at?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Where are you going?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Going! Nay, no where—ſhe's alarmed—Miſs Aubrey, I have a fooliſh notion in my head, that Mr. Tyrrel's in this houſe.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: No, on my word—ſhall I light you to your room?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So ready!—No; your own will ſerve: I can adjuſt my head-dreſs at your glaſs—Hey-dey; all's faſt—you've locked the door—

sp.speaker: Aug
sp.p: Have I, indeed?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, have you, Madam; and, if my ſuſpicion's true, your lover's in it—open it.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I beg to be excuſed.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh! are you caught at laſt? Admit me.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: You cannot ſure be ſerious—think I've the ſanction of a gueſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ridiculous! I'll raiſe the houſe—let me come to the bell.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Hold! hold! you don't know what you do: for your own ſake deſiſt: to ſave your own confuſion, more than mine, deſiſt, and ſeek no farther.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Madam; if I ſpare you, may the ſhame that waits for you fall on my head.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: At your own peril be it then! Look there (opens and diſcovers Lord Abberville.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
L. Abb.
sp.p: Upon my life, Miſs Bridgemore, my viſit has been entirely innocent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh, yes! I give you perfect credit for your innocence; the hour, the place, your Lordſhip's character, the Lady's compoſure, all are innocence itſelf. Can't you affect a little ſurprize, Ma'am, at finding a Gentleman in your bed-room, though you placed him there yourſelf? So excellent an actreſs might pretend a fit on the occaſion: Oh, you have not half your part.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Indeed, Miſs Bridgemore, you look upon this in too ſerious a light.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, be aſſured: I'm charmed with your addreſs; you are a perfect faſhionable lover: ſo agreeable to invite us to your houſe, ſo well bred to be from home, and ſo conſiderate to viſit poor Miſs Aubrey in our abſence: altogether, I am puzzled which to prefer, your wit, politeneſs, or your honour.

sp.speaker: Aug.
Luc.
sp.p: O Madam, with Lord Abberville's protection you may ſet that at nought: to him I recommend you: your company in this houſe will not be very welcome.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p:
Then, Madam, ſhe ſhall come to mine; my houſe, my arms are open to receive
her. Fear nothing, ſet her at defiance; reſign yourſelf to my protection; you ſhall face your tyrant, out-face her, ſhine above her, put her down in ſplendor as in beauty; be no more the ſervile thing her cruelty has made you; but be the life, the leader of each public pleaſure, the envy of all womankind, the miſtreſs of my happineſs—

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: And murderer of my own. No, no, my Lord, I'll periſh firſt: the laſt ſurviving orphan of a noble houſe, I'll not diſgrace it: from theſe mean, unfeeling people, who to the bounty of my anceſtors owe all they have, I ſhall expect no mercy; but you, whom even pride might teach ſome virtue, you to tempt me, you with unmanly cunning to ſeduce diſtreſs yourſelf created, ſinks you deeper in contempt than Heaven ſinks me in poverty and ſhame.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: A very unpromiſing campaign truly: one lady loſt, and the other in no way of being gained. Well, I'll return to my company; there is this merit however in gaming, that it makes all loſſes appear trivial but its own.

SO! ſo! another day; another twelve hours round of folly and extravagance: 'pſhaw! I'm ſick on't. What is it our men of genius are about? Jarring and jangling with each other, while a vaſt army of vices over-runs the whole country at diſcretion (Jarvis enters.) Now, Jarvis, what's your news?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: My morning budget, Sir; a breakfaſt of good deeds; the offerings of a full heart and the return of an empty purſe. There, Sir, I've done your errand; and wiſh hereafter you could find another agent for your charities.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Why ſo, Charles?

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Becauſe the taſk grows heavy; beſides, I'm old and fooliſh, and the ſight is too affecting.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p: Why doesn't do like me then? Sheath a ſoft heart in a rough caſe, 'twill wear the longer; fineer thyſelf, good Jarvis, as thy maſter does, and keep a marble outſide to the world. Who dreams that I am the lewd fool of pity, and thou my pandar, Jarvis, my provider? You ſound out the poor fellow then, the half-pay officer I met laſt Sunday—

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: With difficulty; for he obtruded not his ſorrows on the world, but in deſpair had crept into a corner, and, with his wretched family about him, was patiently expiring.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Pr'ythee no more on't: you ſav'd him; you reliev'd him; no matter how; you made a fellow creature happy, that's enough.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: I did, Sir; but his ſtory's ſo affecting—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Keep it to thyſelf, old man, then; why muſt my heart be wrung? I too am one of Nature's ſpoilt children, and havn't yet left off the tricks of the nurſery.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Tyrrel's come to town, and begs to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Let him come in (Tyrrel enters.) So, nephew, what bring's you to town? I thought you was a priſoner in the country.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I was; but now Lord Courtland has obtained his liberty, no reaſon holds why I ſhould not recover mine.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, Sir, how have you fill'd up your time? In practiſing freſh thruſts, or repenting of that which is paſt? You've drawn your ſword to ſatisfy one man, now think of ſatisfying the reſt of mankind.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
Mort.
sp.p: Yes, honour: you young men are ſubtle arguers; the cloak of honour covers all your faults, as that of paſſion all your follies.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Honour is what mankind have made it: and as we hold our lives upon theſe terms, with our lives it behoves us to defend them.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You have made it reaſon then it ſeems, make it religion too, and put it out of faſhion with the world at once: of this be ſure, I had ſooner caſt my guineas in the ſea, than give 'em to a duelliſt. But come, Frank, you are one from prejudice, not principle; therefore we'll talk no more on't. Where are you lodged?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: At the hotel hard by.

sp.speaker: Mort.
Tyr.
sp.p: O, Sir, unleſs you can conſent to hear the praiſes of my lovely girl, from hour to hour, in endleſs repetition, never ſuffer me within your doors.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Thy girl, Frank, is every thing but rich, and that's a main blank in the catalogue of a Lady's perfections.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Fill it up then, dear Uncle; a word of your's will do it.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: True, boy, a word will do it; but 'tis a long word, 'tis a laſting one; it ſhould be, therefore, a deliberate one: but let me ſee your girl; I'm a ſour fellow; ſo the world thinks of me; but it is againſt the proud, the rich I war: poverty may be a misfortune to Miſs Aubrey; it would be hard to make it an objection.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: How generous is that ſentiment!—Let me have your conſent for my endeavours at obtaining her's, and I ſhall be moſt happy.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: About it then; my part is ſoon made ready; your's is the taſk: you are to find out happineſs in marriage; I'm only to provide you with a fortune. (Exit Tyr.) Well, Frank, I ſuſpected thou hadſt more courage than wit, when I heard of thy engaging in a duel; now thou art for encount'ring a wife, I am convinc'd of it. A wife! 'ſdeath, ſure ſome planetary madneſs reigns amongſt our wives; the dogs-ſtar never ſets, and the moon's horns are fallen on our heads.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: The gude time o'day to you, gude Maiſter Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, Colin, what's the news at your houſe?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Nay, no great ſpell of news, gude faith; aw things with us gang on after the auld ſort. I'm weary of my life amongſt 'em; the murrain take 'em all, ſike a family of free-booters, Maiſter Mortimer; an I ſpeak a word to 'em, or preach up a little needful oeconomy, hoot! the whole clan is up in arms. I may ſpeak it in your ear, an' the de'el himſell was to turn houſe-keeper, he cou'd na' pitch upon a fitter ſet; fellows of all trades, countries and occupations; a ragamuffin crew; the very refuſe of the mob, that canna' count paſt twa generations without a gibbet in their ſcutcheon.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Ay, Colin, things are miſerably chang'd ſince your old maſter died.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ah, Maiſter Mortimer, it makes my heart drop blude to think how much gude counſel I ha' caſt away upon my Laird; ifaith I hanna' ſtinted him o'that; I gee'd him rules and maxims of gude huſbandry in plenty; but aw in vain; the dice ha' deafen'd him.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.p:
Yes, and deſtroy'd; his head, heart, happineſs,
are gone to ruin; the leaſt a gameſter loſes, is his money.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ecod and that's no trifle in his caſe: laſt night's performances made no ſmall hole in that.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Whence learn you that?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: From little Napthali of St. Mary Axe: when a man borrows money of a Jew, 'tis a preſumption no Chriſtian can be found to lend him any.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Is your Lord driven to ſuch wretched ſhifts?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Hoot! know you not that every loſing gameſter has his Jew? He is your only doctor in a deſperate caſe; when the regulars have brought you to Death's door, the quack is invited to uſher you in.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Your Jew, Colin, in the preſent caſe, ſavours more of the lawyer than the doctor; for I take if he makes you ſign and ſeal as long as you have effects.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: You've hit the nail o' the hede; my Laird will ſign to any thing; there's bonds, and blanks, and bargains, and promiſary notes, and a damn'd ſight of rogueries, depend on't. Ecod he had a bundle for his breakfaſt, as big as little Napthali cou'd carry; I wou'd it had braken his bock; and yet he is na' half the knave of yon fat fellow upon Fiſh-ſtreet Hill.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Bridgemore, you mean.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he's at the bottom of the plot; this little Hebrew's only his jackall.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I comprehend you; Bridgemore, under cover of this Jew, has been playing the uſurer with Lord Abberville, and means to pay his daughter's portion in parchment; this muſt be prevented.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: You may ſpare your pains for that; the match is off.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Hey-day, friend Colin, what has put off that?

sp.speaker: Colin.
Mort.
sp.p: Well, as my Lord has got rid of Miſs, I think he may very well ſpare her fortune.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Odzooks, but that's no reaſon he ſhou'd loſe his own.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: That, Colin, may be paſt my power to hinder; yet even that ſhall be attempted: find out the Jew that Bridgemore has employ'd, and bring him hither, if you can.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Let me alone for that; there never was a Jew ſince Samſon's time that Colin cou'd na' deal with; an' he hangs bock, and will na' follow kindly, troth, I'll lug him to you by the ears; ay, will I, and his Maiſter the fat fellow into the bargain.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: No, no, leave me to deal with Bridgemore; I'll ſcare away that cormorant; if the ſon of my noble friend will be undone, it never ſhall be ſaid he fell without an effort on my part to ſave him.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: By Heaven you ſpeak that like a noble Gentleman. Ah, Maiſter Mortimer, in England, he that wants money, wants every thing; in Scotland now, few have it, but every one can do without it.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: But what is all this to me, Doctor? while I have a good houſe over my head, what care I if the Pyramids of Egypt were ſunk into the earth? London, thank Heaven, will ſerve my turn.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ay, ay, look ye, I never ſaid it was'nt coot enough for them that live in it.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Good enough! why what is like it? where can you live ſo well?

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: No where, coot truth, 'tis all cooks ſhops and putchers ſhambles; your very ſtreets have ſavoury names; your Poultry, your Pye-corner, and Pudding-lane, your Bacon-alley, and Fiſh-ſtreet Hill here; o' my oord, the Map of London, would furniſh out an admirable pill of fare for a Lord-Mayor's dinner.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, Doctor, I'm contented with Fiſh-ſtreet Hill; you may go ſeek for lodgings yonder in the ruins Of Palmyra.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ruins indeed! what are all your new buildings, up and down yonder, but ruins? Improve your town a little further, and you'll drive every man of ſenſe out of it; pleſs us, and ſave us, bye and bye not a monument of antiquity will be left ſtanding from London-ſtone to Weſtminſter-hall.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: And if the Commiſſioners of paving would mend the ſtreets with one, and preſent t'other as a nuſance, bone ſetters and lawyers would be the only people to complain.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Down with 'em then at once, down with every thing noble and venerable and antient amongſt you; turn the Tower of London into a Pantheon, make a new Adelphi of the Savoy, and bid adieu to all ages but your own; you will then be no more in the way of deriving dignity from your progenitors, than you are of tranſmitting it to your poſterity.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, Doctor, well, leave me my opinion and keep your own; you've a veneration for ruſt and cobwebs, I am for bruſhing them off wherever I meet them; we are for furniſhing our ſhops and warehouſes with good profitable commodities; you are for ſtoring 'em with all the monſters of the creation: I much doubt if we cou'd ſerve you with a dried rattleſnake, or a ſtuft alligator, in all the purlieus of Fiſh-ſtreet Hill.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: A ſtuft alligator! a ſtuft alderman wou'd be ſooner had.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: May be ſo, and let me tell you an antiquarian is as much to ſeek in the city of London, as an alderman wou'd be in the ruins of Herculaneum: every man after his own way, that's my maxim: you are for the paltry ore; I am for the pure gold; I dare be ſworn now, you are as much at home amongſt the ſnakes and ſerpents at Don Saltero's as I am with the Jews and jobbers at Jonathan's.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Coot truth, Mr. Pridgemore, 'tis hard to ſay which collection is the moſt harmleſs of the two.
I'm out of patience with you, Mr. Bridgemore, to ſee you ſtir no briſker in this buſineſs; with ſuch a ſtorm about your ears, you ſtand as idle as a Dutch ſailor in a trade wind.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Truly, love, till you come in, I heard nothing of the ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Recollect the miſadventure of laſt night, the wickedneſs of that ſtrumpet you have harboured in your houſe; that viper, which wou'd never have had ſtrength to ſting, hadn't you warm'd it in your boſom.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p:
Faith and truth now, I hav'nt heard better reaſoning from an ooman this many a day; you ſhall know Mr. Pridgemore, the viperous ſpecies love warmth; their ſting, look ye, is then more venomous; but draw
their teeth, and they are harmleſs reptiles; the conjurors in Perſia play a thouſand fancies and fagaries with 'em.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: But I'm no Perſian, Doctor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: No, nor conjuror neither; you wou'd not elſe have been the dupe thus of a paltry girl.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: A girl, indeed! why all the European world are made the dupes of girls; the Aſiatics are more wiſe; ſaving your preſence now, I've ſeen a Turkiſh Pacha or a Tartar Chan rule threeſcore, ay, three hundred wives, with infinite more eaſe and quiet, than you can manage one.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Manage your butterflies, your bats and beetles, and leave the government of wives to thoſe who have 'em: we ſtand on Britiſh ground as well as our huſbands; Magna Charta is big enough for us both; our bill of divorce is a full match for their bill of rights at any time: we have our Commons, Doctor, as well as the men, and I believe our privileges are as well manag'd here at St. Paul's, as their's are yonder at St. Stephen's.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Your privileges, Mrs. Pridgemore, are not to be diſputed by any in this company; and if Miſs is as well inſtructed in her's, I wiſh my Lord Abberville joy of his releaſe; that's all.
What did the fellow ſay? who ſent that old mummy hither?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: He came upon a qualifying meſſage from Lord Abberville, as I believe; but 'tis ſuch an extravagant old blade, he got amongſt the pyramids of Egypt, before he could well bring it out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: I wou'd he was there, and his pupil with him: don't you ſee what a condition our poor girl is thrown into?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I into a condition! No; they ſhall never have to ſay they threw me into a condition: I may be angry, but I ſcorn to own I'm diſappointed.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: That's right, child, ſure there are more men in the world, beſides Lord Abberville.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Law, papa! your ideas are ſo groſs, as if I car'd for any of the ſex, if he hadn't ſingled her out from all women kind; but it was ever thus; ſhe's born to be my
evil genius; ſure the men are mad—Tyrrel, Lord Abberville—one touch'd my heart, the other wounds my pride.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Why, ay, there is a fine eſtate, a noble title, great connections, powerful intereſt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Revenge is worth them all; drive her but out of doors, and marry me to a convent.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: But let us keep ſome ſhew of juſtice; this may be all a frolic of Lord Abberville's; the girl, perhaps, is innocent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How can that be, when I am miſerable?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Come, ſhe's been ſuffer'd in your houſe too long; had I been miſtreſs, ſhe ſhou'd have quitted it laſt night upon the inſtant: wou'd ſhe had never entred it.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: There you make a bad wiſh, Mrs. Bridgemore; ſhe has proved the beſt feather in my wing; but call her down; go, daughter, call her down.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'll ſend her to you; nothing ſhall prevail with me to ſpeak to her, or look upon the odious creature more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: What is it you are always hinting at about this girl? ſhe's the beſt feather in your wing. Explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I can't; you muſt excuſe me; 'tis better you ſhou'd never know it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Why, where's the fear; what can you have to dread from a deſtitute girl, without father, and without friend?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: But is ſhe really without father? was I once well aſſured of that—But huſh! my daughter's here—Well, where's Miſs Aubrey?

div.stage: LUCINDA enters followed by a MAID SERVANT.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The bird is flown.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Hey-day, gone off!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: That's flat conviction.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: What have you there? a letter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: She found it on her table.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Read it, Lucy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I beg to be excuſed, Sir; I don't chuſe to touch her naſty ſcrawl.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well then, let's ſee; I'll read it myſelf.

Sir, Since neither Lord Abberville's teſtimony, nor my moſt ſolemn proteſtations can prevail with you to believe me innocent, I prevent Miſs Bridgemore's threaten'd diſmiſſion by withdrawing myſelf for ever from your family: how the world will receive a deſtitute defenceleſs orphan I am now to prove; I enter on my trial without any armour but my innocence; which, though inſufficient to ſecure to me the continuance of your confidence, will, by the favour of Providence, ſerve, I hope, to ſupport me under the loſs of it.
Auguſta Aubrey.
So! ſhe's elop'd.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Ay, this is lucky; there's an end of her: this makes it her own act and deed; give me the letter, go, you need not wait. (to the ſervant.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Don't you hear? leave the room.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Pray don't be angry; I beg to ſpeak a word to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go, go, another time; I'm buſy.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I've done a wicked thing, and if I don't diſcharge my heart, 'twill break, it is ſo full.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: What have you done? ſpeak out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why I have been the means of ruining an innocent perſon, for ſuch Miſs Aubrey is.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: How ſo? go on.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: 'Twas I that brought Lord Abberville laſt night into her chamber, unknown to her; I thought it was a little frolic to ſurpriſe her; but when I heard her ſcream, I was alarmed and ran and liſtened at the door.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Why then I heard her chide him, and deſire him to be gone; yes, and but juſt before you came up ſtairs, I heard the poor young Lady reproach him bitterly for his baſeneſs in making love to her, when he was engaged to you, Madam: indeed, ſhe is as innocent as the babe unborn.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go your way for a ſimpleton, and ſay no more about the matter.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: To be ſure I was a ſimpleton to do as I did; but I ſhou'd never ſurvive it, if any miſchief was to follow.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: What's to be done now?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: What's to be done? why let her take her courſe; guilty or not, what matters it, if every man who offers for your daughter, is to turn aſide and follow after her?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: True, where's the woman who can pardon that? indeed, had ſhe been really criminal, I cou'd have endur'd her better, for then I had had one qualification, which ſhe had wanted; now ſhe piques me every way.
Lord Abberville, Madam, deſires to be admitted to ſay a word to you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who? Lord Abberville?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Oh, by all means admit him; now, Lucy, ſhow yourſelf a woman of ſpirit; receive him, meet his inſulting viſit with becoming contempt: Come, Mr. Bridgemore, let us leave them to themſelves.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ahem, now, pride, ſupport me!

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Miſs Bridgemore, your moſt obedient; I come, Madam, on a penitential errand, to apologize to you and Miſs Aubrey for the ridiculous ſitutation in which I was ſurpriſed laſt night.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Cool, eaſy villain! (aſide)

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: I dare ſay you laugh'd moſt heartily after I was gone.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Moſt incontinently-incomparable aſſurance! (aſide.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Well, I forgive you; 'twas ridiculous enough; a fooliſh frolick, but abſolutely harmleſs be aſſur'd: I'm glad to find you no longer ſerious about it—But where's Miſs Aubrey, pray?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You'll find her probably at your own door, ſhe's gone from hence.
Mr. Tyrrel, Madam.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Show him in, pray—My Lord, you've no objection.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: None in life; I know him intimately; but if you pleaſe, I'll take my leave; you may have buſineſs—Curſe on't, he is the Lady's lover. (aſide.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, I inſiſt upon your ſtaying—Now malice ſtand my friend!—Good morning to you, Sir, you're welcome to town.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I thank you—I am wrong I believe; your ſervant ſhould not have ſhewn me in here: 'tis with Miſs Aubrey I requeſt to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Lord Abberville, you can direct Mr. Tyrrel to Miſs Aubrey: ſhe has left this family, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Madam—My Lord—I beg to know—I don't underſtand—

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Nor I, upon my ſoul: was ever any thing ſo malicious? (aſide.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My Lord, why don't you ſpeak? Mr. Tyrrel may have particular buſineſs with Miſs Aubrey.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Why do you refer to me? How ſhou'd I know any thing of Miſs Aubrey?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, I aſk pardon; perhaps Mr. Tyrrel's was a mere viſit of compliment.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Excuſe me, Madam; I confeſs it was an errand of the moſt ſerious ſort.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then it's cruel not to tell him where you've plac'd her.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Plac'd her!

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Ay, plac'd her indeed? For Heaven's ſake, what are you about?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, I have done, my Lord; but after laſt night's fatal diſcovery, I conceived you wou'd no longer affect any privacy as to your ſituation with Miſs Aubrey.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: What did you diſcover laſt night, Madam, tell me; I have an intereſt in the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for't, for then you'll not be pleas'd to hear that ſhe admits Lord Abberville, by night, into her bedroom; locks him up in it, and on detection the next morning, openly avows her guilt, by eloping to her galant.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: What do I hear? My Lord, my Lord, if this is true—

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What then? what if it is? muſt I account to you? who makes you my inquiſitor?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Juſtice, humanity, and that controul which virtue gives me over it's oppoſers: if more you wou'd, with anguiſh I confeſs my heart unhappily was plac'd on her whom you have ruin'd; now you'll not diſpute my right.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: This is no place to urge your right; I ſhall be found at home.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I'll wait upon you there.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Do ſo—your ſervant—Miſs Bridgemore, I am infinitely your debtor for this agreeable viſit; I leave you to the enjoyment of your many amiable virtues, and the pleaſing contemplation of what may probably enſue from the interview you have provided for me with Mr. Tyrrel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I muſt be leſs or more than woman, if I did not reliſh this retaliation.

div.stage: The Street, with a diſtant View of a Square.

sp.p: AH, Colin, thou'rt a prodigal; a thriftleſs loon thou'ſt been, that cou'd na' keep a little pelf to thyſall when thou had'ſt got it; now thou may'ſt gang in this poor geer to thy live's end, and worſe too for aught I can tell; 'faith, mon, 'twas a ſmeart little byſack of money thou hadſt ſcrap'd together, an the beſt part of it had na' been laft amongſt thy kinsfolk, in the Iſles of Skey and Mull; muckle gude may it do the weams of them that ha' it! There was Jamie Mac Gregor and Sawney Mac Nab, and the twa braw lads of Kinruddin, with old Charley Mac Dougall, my mother's firſt huſband's ſecond couſin: by my ſol I cou'd na' ſee ſuch near relations, and gentlemen of fich auncient families gang upon bare feet, while I rode a horſeback: I had been na true Scot, an I cou'd na' ge'en a countryman a gude laft upon occaſion (as he is going out, Miſs Aubrey enters.)

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: That houſe is Mr. Mortimer's; and yet I can't reſolve to go to it: to appeal to Tyrrel is a dangerous ſtep; it plunges him again in my unproſperous concerns, and puts his life a ſecond time in danger; ſtill, ſtill I know not how to let him think me guilty: wretched, unfriended creature that I am, what ſhall I do? (as ſhe is going out, Colin advances.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Haud a bit, laſſie, you that are bewailing; what's your malady?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Sir! Did you ſpeak to me?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Troth, did I; I were loth to let affliction paſs beſide me and not aſk it what it ail'd.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Do you know me then?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: What need have I to know you? An you can put me in the way to help you, isn't that enough?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I thank you: if I have your pity, that is all my caſe admits of.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Wha' can tell that? I may be better than I ſeem: as ſorry a figure as I cut, I have as gude blude in my veins, and as free of it too, as any Breton in the londe; troth, an you be of my country, Madam, you may have heard as much.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I do not queſtion it; but I am not of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Colin.
Aug.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you ſeem to wiſh to do me ſervice: I've a letter here; I cannot well deliver it myſelf; if you are of this neighbourhood, perhaps you know the houſe of Mr. Mortimer.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Hoot! hoot! I ken him well; I came fra' thence but now.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Will you take charge of this, and give it as directed? The Gentleman will be found at Mr. Mortimer's.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: To Francis Tyrrel, Eſquire—Ah! an 'tis thereabouts you point, gadzooks, your labour's loſt; you may ev'n wear the willow as they ſay, for by my troth he'll play the loon wi' you.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Is that his character?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No; but he canna' well be true to twa at the ſame time.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: His heart's engag'd it ſeems: what is the Lady's name?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Woe worth her name! I canna' recollect it now; an it had been a Scottiſh name, I ſhou'd na let it ſlip ſo; but I've no mighty memory for your Engliſh callings; they do na dwell upon my tongue: out on't! 'tis with a grete fat lubber yonder in the city that ſhe dwells; a fellow with a paunch below his gullet, like the poke of a pelican; and now I call to mind, 'tis Aubrey is her name; ay, ay, 'tis Aubrey; ſhe's the happy woman.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p:
Is ſhe the happy woman? Well, Sir, if you'll deliver that letter into Mr. Tyrrel's hands; there is no
treaſon in it againſt Miſs Aubrey; ſhe herſelf is privy to the contents.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: You need na' doubt but I ſhall honde it to him; I were a ſorry child an I cou'd grudge you that: where ſhall I bring his anſwer?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: It requires none.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: But an he craves to know your houſe, where mun I ſay you dwell?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I have no houſe, no home, no father, friend, or refuge, in this world; nor do I at this moment, fainting as I am with affliction and fatigue, know where to find a hoſpitable door.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Come with me then, and I will ſhow you one; ah! woe is me, we hanna' all cold hearts, that occupy cold climates: I were a graceleſs loon indeed, when Providence ha' done ſo much for me, an' I cou'd not pay bock a little to a fellow creature.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Who you may be I know not, but that ſentiment perſwades me I may truſt you; know, in this wretched perſon you behold her whom you think the envied, the belov'd Miſs Aubrey.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Miſs Aubrey! you Miſs Aubrey! His preſence be about us! And has that grete fat fellow in the city turn'd his bock upon you? Out on him, ugly hound, his ſtomach be his grave! I cou'd find in my heart to ſtick my dirk into his weam.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Have patience; 'tis not he, Lord Abberville's the ſource of my misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ah, woe the while the more's his ſhame, I'd rather hear that he were dead.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Do not miſtake affliction for diſgrace; I'm innocent.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I ſee it in your face: wou'd I cou'd ſay as much of him.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: You know him then.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, and his father afore him: Colin Macleod's my name.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Colin Macleod!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: What do you ſtart at? Troth, there's no ſhame upon't; 'tis nought a bit the worſe for my wear; honeſty was aw my patrimony, and by my ſol I hanna ſpent it: I ſerve Lord Abberville, but not his vices.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p:
I readily believe you; and to convince you of it, put me, I beſeech you, into ſome preſent ſhelter, till the
labour of my hands can keep me, and hold me up but for a breathing ſp • ce, till I can rally my exhauſted ſpirits and learn to ſtruggle with the world.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, will I by my ſol, ſo Heaven gives life, and woe betide the child that does you wrong! I be na ſmuthly ſpoken, but you ſhall find me true.—And look, the firſt door that I caſt my ey'n upon, I ken the name of Macintoſh; troth, 'tis a gudely omen and prognoſtic: the Macintoſhes and Macleods are aw of the ſame blood fra' long antiquity: had we ſearch'd aw the town we cou'd na' find a better. (Knocks at the door.) Odzooks, fear nothing, damſel, an ſhe be a true Macintoſh, you need na' doubt a welcome. (MRS. MACINTOSH comes to the door.) Gude day to you, Madam, is your name Macintoſh pray you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: It is; what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Nay, hau'd a bit, gude child, we command nought; but being, d'ye ſee, a Scottiſh kinſman of your's, Colin Macleod by name, I crave a lodgment in your houſe for this poor laſſie.—Gude troth you need na ſquant at her ſo cloſely; there's nought to be ſuſpected; and tho' ſhe may na' boaſt ſo long a pedigree as you and I do, yet for an Engliſh family, ſhe's of no deſpicable houſe; and as for reputation, gude faith the lamb is not more innocent: reſpecting mine own fall I will na' vaunt, but an' you've any doubts, you need na' gang a mighty length to ſatisfy 'em; I'm no impoſtor.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: I ſee enough to ſatisfy me; ſhe is a perfect beauty:—pray, young Lady, walk in; pray walk up ſtairs, you are heartily welcome; lackaday, you ſeem piteouſly fatigu'd.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Indeed I want repoſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Reſt you awhile; I'll deliver your letter and call on you anon.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Heavens, what a lovely girl!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Haud you a bit, you've done this kindly, couſin Macintoſh, but were na' come a bagging, d'ye ſee; here, take this money in your honde and let her want for nought.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: You may depend upon my care.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I ken'd you for a Macintoſh at once; I am na' apt to be miſtaken in any of your clan; and 'tis a comely preſence that you have; troth 'tis the caſe with aw of you; the Macintoſhes are a very perſonable people.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Another of my Scottiſh couſins—Oh, this new name of mine is a moſt thriving invention; a rare device to hook in cuſtomers; when I was plain Nan Rawlins of St. Martin's pariſh, ſcarce a yard of ferret cou'd I fell to club a prentice's hair on a Sunday morning; now there's not a Knight of the Thiſtle that does not wear my green paduaſoy acroſs his ſhoulder, nor a Mac paſſes my ſhop who does not buy ſnuff and black ribband of his kinſwoman; of ſuch conſequence is it to have a good name in this world.

div.stage: A room in LORD ABBERVILLE's houſe.
LORD ABBERVILLE enters, followed by ſeveral ſervants.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: You are a moſt unreaſonable ſet of gentry truly; I have but one Scotchman in my family, and you are every one of you, cook, valet, butler, up in arms to drive him out of it.

sp.speaker: La Jeu.
sp.p: And with reaſon, my Lord; Monſieur Colin is a grand financier; but he has a little of what we call la maladie du päys; he is too oeconomique; it is not for the credit of mi Lord Anglois to be too oeconomique.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: I think, La Jeuneſſe, I have been at ſome pains to put that out of diſpute; but get you gone all together, and ſend the fellow to me; I begin to be as tir'd of him as you are.— (Exeunt ſervants.)—His honeſty is my reproach; theſe raſcals flatter while they rob me: it angers me that one, who has no ſtake, no intereſt in my fortune, ſhould huſband it more frugally than I who am the owner and the ſufferer: in ſhort, he is the glaſs in which I ſee myſelf, and the reflection tortures me; my vices have deform'd me; gaming has made a monſter of me.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Well, is the ſavage coming?

sp.speaker: La Jeu.
sp.p: He is only turning his cravat, my Lord, and will be here immediately.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
Colin.
sp.p:
Saving your preſence I ſhou'd gueſs a pratty many
lies; 'twill moſtly be the caſe when companions in office give characters one of another.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: But what is he, whom nobody ſpeaks well of? You are given up on all hands.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: And ſo muſt truth itſall, when the de'el turns hiſtorian.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: You've been applauded for your bluntneſs; 'tis no recommendation to me, Macleod; nor ſhall I part from all my family to accommodate your ſpleen: from the ſtable-boy to my own valet, there's not a domeſtic in this houſe gives you a good word.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Nor ever will, till I prefer their intereſt to your's; hungry curs will bark; but an' your Lordſhip wou'd have us regale our friends below ſtairs, while you are feaſting your's above, gadzooks, I have a pratty many countrymen in town, with batter appetites than purſes, will applaud the regulation.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: 'Tis for ſuch purſes and ſuch appetites you would be a fit provider; 'tis for the latitude of the Highlands, not for the meridian of London, your narrow ſcale of oeconomy is laid down.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Oeconomy is no diſgrace; 'tis batter living on a little, than outliving a grate deal.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may be honeſt, but you are troubleſome; my family are one and all in arms againſt you; and you muſt know, Colin Macleod, I've great objection to a rebellion either in a family or ſtate, whatever you and your countrymen may think of the matter.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord; whan you have ſhad the blude of the offenders, it is na' generous to revive the offence: as for mine awn particular, Heaven be my judge, the realm of England does na' haud a heart more loyal than the one I ſtrike my honde upon.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: So, Doctor, what's the news with you?—Well, Colin, let me hear no more of theſe complaints; don't be ſo conſiderate of me—and hark'e, if you was not quite ſo parſimonious to yourſelf, your appearance would be all the better.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Troth, I'd be better habited, but I canna' afford it.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Afford it, ſirrah? don't I know you have money enough, if you had but ſpirit to make uſe of it?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: True; but I fain wou'd keep a little together, d'ye ſee, leſt you ſhou'd not.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Pleſſing upon us, how the man prates and prattles! 'Twas but this morning he was differing and diſputing truly about pedigrees and antiquities, tho' I can count forty and four generations from the grandmother of Saint Winifred, as regularly as a Monk can tell his beads.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Leave your generations to the worms, Doctor, and tell me if you carried my meſſage to Bridgemore—But why do I aſk that? when I myſelf am come from putting the finiſhing hand to that treaty: and really if young women will keep companions, who are handſomer than themſelves, they muſtn't wonder if their lovers go aſtray.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ah my Lord Apperville, my Lord Apperville, you've ſomething there to anſwer for.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Preach not, good ſixty-five, thy cold continence to twenty-three; the ſtars are in my debt one lucky throw at leaſt; let them beſtow Miſs Aubrey, and I'll cancel all that's paſt. (A Servant delivers a letter) what have we here?—from Tyrrel I ſuppoſe—no, 'tis from a more peaceable quarter; my commodious Mrs. Macintoſh. (Reads)— "Chance has thrown in my way a girl, that quite eclipſes your Miſs Somers: come to me without loſs of time, leſt the bird ſhould be on the wing."—What ſhall I do? I have but little ſtomach to the buſineſs. Aubrey is my goddeſs, and 'tis downright hereſy to follow any other. (Another Servant enters.)

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, a perſon without ſays he comes with a recommendation from Sir Harry Gamble.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What ſort of a perſon?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A little ugly fellow; I believe he's a Jew.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: That's right, I had forgot: my Jew is fairly jaded; Sir Harry's probably is better trained; ſo let me ſee him: who is in the antichamber?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: There are ſeveral perſons waiting to ſpeak with your Lordſhip; they have called a great many times.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p:
Ay, ay, they come for money, he alone comes with it; therefore conduct that little ugly fellow as you call him to my cloſet, and bid thoſe other people call again. [Exit Servant.] Doctor, if any of my particulars
are importunate to ſee me, don't let 'em interrupt me here; tell 'em I'm gone to Mrs. Mackintoſh's; they'll know the place, and my buſineſs in it.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: They may gueſs that without the gift of divination truly: Ah! this paſſion is the prejudice of education! he may thank France and Italy for this: I would have carried him through Ingria, Eſthonia, and Livonia; through Moldavia, Beſſarabia, Bulgaria, Thrace; from the Gulph of Finland to the Streights of the Dardanelles. 'Tis a chance if he had ſeen a human creature in the whole courſe of his travels.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Doctor, forgive me this intruſion; where is Lord Abberville? his ſervants deny him to me, and I've buſineſs with him of a preſſing ſort.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Buſineſs indeed!

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Yes, buſineſs, Sir: I beg you to inform me where to find him.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: I take it, Mr. Tyrrel, you are one of his particulars, therefore I tell you he is gone to Mrs. Macintoſh's; a commodious ſort of a pody, who follows one trade in her ſhop, and another in her parlour.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know her well, and know his buſineſs there.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Pleaſure is all his buſineſs; I take for granted he finds ſome gratification in his viſits there.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Yes, the gratification of a devil, the pleaſure of defacing beauty and deſpoiling innocence, of planting everlaſting miſery in the human heart for one licentious tranſitory joy: 'tis there he holds his riots, thither he is gone to repeat his triumphs over my unhappy Aubrey, and confirm her in her ſhame.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ay, I ſuppoſe Miſs Aubrey is the reigning paſſion now.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Curs'd be his paſſions, wither'd be his powers! Oh, Sir, ſhe was an angel once: ſuch was the graceful modeſty of her deportment, it ſeemed as if the chaſtity, which now ſo many of her ſex throw from them, centered all with her.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p:
I've told too much; this lad's as mad as he—well, Mr. Tyrrel, I can ſay but little in the caſe;
women and politics I never deal in; in other words I abhor cuckoldom, and have no paſſion for the pillory.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Gang your gait for an old ſmoak-dried piece of goat's-fleſh (ſhuts the door.) Now we're alone, young Gentleman, there's ſomething for your private reading. (Delivers a letter.)

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: What do I ſee? Miſs Aubrey's hand! Why does ſhe write to me? Diſtraction, how this racks my heart!

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, and mine too—ecod, it gave it ſike a pull, I canna for the ſol of me, get it bock into it's place again: gude truth, you'll find it but a melancholy tale.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: (reads) "I am the martyr of an accident, which never will find credit; under this ſtroke I can't conceal a wiſh that Mr. Tyrrel would not give me up; but as his ſingle oppoſition to the world's reproach might be as dangerous to him, as it muſt be Ineffectual to me, I earneſtly adviſe him to forget the unfortunate Auguſta."—What am I to conclude? The paper looks like innocence, the words as ſoft as modeſty cou'd utter.—The martyr of an accident! She calls it accident; why that's no crime. Alas! it might be accident, which threw temptation in her way, but voluntary guilt, which yielded to the tempter: of him ſhe makes no mention. Pray, Sir, inform me; you have ſeen this Lady—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Diſcours'd with her—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: In that diſcourſe do you recollect if ſhe named Lord Abberville?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I recollect ſhe ſaid he was the ſource of her miſfortunes.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Ay, did ſhe ſay ſo much? That's guilty beyond doubt.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: You're right; it carries a damn'd guilty look: I wou'd na take his fortune to father his faults.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Why you then give him up. Oh! 'tis too palpable! But, pray, did ſhe herſelf give you this letter for me?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p:
With her own hondes; gude faith, the heart
within you wou'd ha malted to have ſeen the manner of it.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: That aggravates my torture! Where was it you left her? In what wretched habitation?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Hoot! no diſparagement upon her habitation; there's nought of wretchedneſs about it: odzooks! ſhe's with a Lady of as gude a family!—But you mun be as cloſe as wax, d'ye ſee, you munna mang the ſecret to my Laird.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Well, well, the place—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis hard by; a couſin's of mine own; a comely courteous woman as you'd wiſh to commune with; one Mrs. Macintoſh.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! that confirms it! There, Sir, bring me no more letters: whether you're dupe or pandar in this buſineſs, I deſire never to be troubled more.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Hoot! what the fiend poſſeſſes you? What time o' the moon is this? The lad's an errant bedlamite. There's miſchief in the wind; and this ſame Laird of mine is at the bottom of it: gadzooks, there goes Maiſter Mortimer; I'll tell him aw the caſe, and take his counſel on the whole.

div.stage: Scene changes to Mrs. MACINTOSH's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Tyrrel, if you muſt and will be heard, you muſt; but pray be ſhort, my time is precious.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: So is my peace of mind: you've got a Lady in your houſe has taken that from me I never ſhall recover.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: What is't you mean? What Lady have I in my houſe?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Miſs Aubrey.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Miſs Aubrey! You miſtake; I never heard the name.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Come, you and I have long been friends: anſwer me truly, does not Lord Abberville viſit a Lady here?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Well, if he does, what then?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Why then that Lady has undone me; ſhe has broke my heart.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Yes; but her name's not Aubrey; my Lord calls her Somers.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Let my Lord call her what he will, coin what new name he pleaſes to elude my ſearch, ſtill I muſt ſee her.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Why you're mad ſure to think of ſuch a thing; I thought you knew me better: violate a truſt? No, no, young man, that's not my principle; you ſee no Lady here. Why, ſure, I've not maintained an honourable character in the world till now, to make away with it at laſt.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: If you ſuſpect me, ſtay and be preſent at our conference.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Mac.
sp.p: Yes, and ſo have my Lord come in and catch us, and a tilting bout enſue betwixt you; no, Mr. Tyrrel, mine's a ſober well conducted family: I'll have no coroner's inqueſt come within my doors—Huſh, as I live, here comes my Lord: dear Tyrrel, be adviſed, come along with me, and betake yourſelf out of his way.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: No; I'll not ſeek a quarrel with Lord Abberville, but I cannot fly from him: go, go, and leave us to each other.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
Tyr.
sp.p: My Lord, when I'm aſſured Miſs Aubrey is in this houſe, and ſee you her viſitor, I can interpret for myſelf.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Miſs Aubrey in this houſe! You rave.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Come, 'tis in vain; your Scotchman told me ſo; your Mrs. Macintoſh herſelf confeſſed it.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Humph! after all, 'twou'd be a lucky hit, ſhould this be true: it may be ſo (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: If you require more witneſſes to what I ſay, here comes an indiſputable one, Miſs Aubrey herſelf.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p:
Oh, Mr. Tyrrel, this is generous indeed! Lord Abberville here too;—'tis what I dreaded. You have
miſchief in your minds; but, I beſeech you, leave me to my misfortunes, nor caſt away one thought upon a wretch like me.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Give me your anſwer firſt to theſe demands. Have you been wrong'd? Have you an accuſation to prefer againſt this Lord, or do you acquit him, and ſubmit with patience to your ſituation?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I accuſe no one; I ſubmit with patience; I am content to be the only ſufferer in this buſineſs, and earneſtly intreat you to deſiſt from any altercation with Lord Abberville on my account.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied; and ſhall religiouſly obey you: Lord Abberville, I aſk your pardon for this interruption; I never ſhall repeat it more.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: But are you going?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: For ever. Dangerous to behold you are; therefore, before my fond my fooliſh heart relapſes into love, I'll ſeize the resolution of the moment, and bid farewell to you for ever.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing!

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: There, Madam, you perceive the love, the honour of that Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Cou'd I have thought this of him? Now I'm truly wretched.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: No, Madam, if my purſe, my perſon, my aſſiduous ardent love can fill the vacancy his falſehood makes, you've had no loſs: dry up your tears, you've yet a friend; ſmile only on my wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: No, my Lord, no; you've made me wretched, guilty you ſhall never make me.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
Aug.
sp.p: What is't you mean, my Lord?—Stand off!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Ay, what is it you mean, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Mortimer! 'ſdeath, what evil genius conducted you hither?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Nay, my good friend, come in. (COLIN enters.) This honeſt man was my conductor: while you, Lord Abberville, in a diſtinguiſh'd rank are openly aſſaulting innocence, he, in his humble poſt is ſecretly ſupporting it.—If you come under that deſcription, Madam, I am your defender; if not, I have no further buſineſs here.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd I urge my innocence? I am unfortunate, I'm poor: your nephew, Sir, will tell you that is cauſe ſufficient for abandoning me.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: This grows too ſerious; I ſcorn to ſteal that from you half my fortune could not purchaſe. I believe you are as innocent as Heaven firſt form'd you; and to convince the world in what eſteem I hold your virtues, here, before Mortimer, I offer you my hand, and lay my title, rank and fortune, at your feet.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: No, there may be a legal proſtitute as well as a licentious one; had you a world to give, after your baſe experiment, you cannot offer any thing that I ſhall take. You may find others leſs exceptious; but in a noble family, though ſtripp'd of fortune, there will ſtill be pride.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: I ſee my fate; I ſee a prepoſſeſſion in your heart too ſtrong for me to ſhake: I plainly perceive that Mr. Tyrrel can offend with more impunity than I can; however, Mortimer, you are a man of honour; I reſign Miſs Aubrey into your hands for the preſent, and ſhall expect you will avail yourſelf of no unfair advantages over me.—Macleod, I find Miſs Aubrey is to thank you for this ſeaſonable viſit of Mr. Mortimer's.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Come, Madam, you are now my ward; Bridgemore muſt ſtruggle hard to get you back again.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Sir!—Mr. Mortimer! You'll pardon me, but muſt I think you ſerious? If what you now propoſe is meant in kindneſs to me, I muſt ſay the world has not done juſtice to your character: I have been taught to look upon you as no friend to our ſex in particular.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Nor am I; your ſex have broke treaty with us, paſs'd the bounds betwixt us, forc'd into our very taverns, and from being once the glory of my country are become it's ſhame.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: But all have not done this—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Nor am I then at enmity with all; a virtuous individual is of no ſex, no country.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: No country? Hoot! A true North Briton will give up his virtue afore his country at any time.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Yes and I think it was a partiality to your country rather than to virtue, which determin'd you to put me into this houſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: De'il take me now and all may kindred with me, if I knew ought about the houſe, more than the name of Macintoſh upon the door.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Time will clear all things up: a general miſconception is gone forth; my nephew I perceive has fallen under it. As for poor Colin, his deſign in bringing you hither was more than innocent, depend upon it, it was noble; I have heard his ſtory and at my requeſt he brings me here: commit yourſelf therefore to my protection and rely upon my juſtice.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: How ſhall I anſwer you? Your generoſity o'erwhelms me.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I generous! No, I am a meer voluptuary; I ſtudy luxury by principle, and am as ſenſual on the ſide of virtue, as Abberville, or any other faſhionable rake, on that of vice.—Colin, you'll ſettle matters with your countrywoman and come to us at my houſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: My countrywoman! The fiend a bit! I never will believe ſhe has a drop of Scottiſh blude in aw her compoſition; as I ſhall anſwer I never bluſh'd before for any of the name: there muſt be ſomething ſpurious in her genealogy: I'll have a little ſerious talk with her on that; I've got the pedigree of the Macintoſhes at my fingers ends, and if there's e'er a flaw in her deſcent 'twixt this and Noah, gadzooks, I'll wager a hundred pounds I prove her an impoſtor.

IF Bridgemore has'nt ſhifted his abode, that is the houſe; 'twas there that eighteen years ago I loſt a wife, and left an infant daughter.
