All-diſpoſing Providence, who haſt ordain'd me to this hour, and thro' innumerable toils and dangers led me back to this affecting ſpot, can it be wonder'd at, if I approach it with an anxious aching heart, uncertain as I am if I have ſtill a child or not? What ſhall I do? If my Auguſta's loſt, 'twere better I ſhould never enter thoſe ill-omen'd doors; if ſhe ſurvives, how ſhall I diſcloſe myſelf, and tell her ſhe has ſtill a father? Oh, that unknown and unperceiv'd, I cou'd but catch a ſight of her, gaze till I'd gratified my longing, and till this throbbing might abate! I'll watch the door till ſomebody comes out, that I may ſpeak to. (Steps aſide.)

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: The murrain light upon this Fiſh-ſtreet Hill, wherever it may be: I wou'd it had na got it's name for nought, that I might fairly ſmall it out, for I am clear bewalder'd. Johnny Grout's houſe wou'd as ſoon be found, as this ſame Bradgemore's. One cries turn o' this honde, one o' that, and t'other ſtares and grins forſooth becauſe I hanna got the modern gabble on my tongue, but ſpeak the language in it's auncient purity. Hoot! this mon ſeems of a batter ſort, and peradventure wou'd concede an anſwer. Speed you, Gentleman, I pray you whuch way leads to Fiſh-ſtreet Hill?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: You are there already; this is Fiſh-ſtreet Hill.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Gadzooks! and that's the reaſon I cou'd find it na' where alſe. Ken you one Bradgemore's may I aſk?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: He had us'd to live in yonder houſe with the great gates; but it is many years ſince I have been in England.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I'faith, you need na' tell me that; I apprehend as much from your civility.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Give me leave now in my turn to aſk you a few queſtions.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: With aw my heart; you have gude right; you may interrogate me freely.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: You are acquainted with this Bridgemore.—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: And with his family—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: And what does it conſiſt of?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Troth, of a ſpouſe and daughter.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Are they all?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, and enow in aw gude reaſon; the de'il, Sir, in his vengeance need na' add a third.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: But to be ſerious, tell me I beſeech you, do you know of no one elſe in Mr. Bridgemore's family?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Of none.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: What do I hear? Pray recollect yourſelf: you don't ſeem to know his houſe; perhaps you are not well acquainted with his family.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Aw that he owns I know; what baſe begotten brats he may haue ſculking up and down in holes and corners, troth, I can't pretend to ſay.—Theſe city cattle ſometimes will break paſture.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: You miſconceive me, honeſt friend; has no young Lady of the name of Aubrey come within your knowledge?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, ay, poor laſſie, ſhe once liv'd with Bradgemore; the worſe luck her's, but that is over; ſhe has got her liberty; ſhe's now releas'd.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I underſtand you—She is dead.—

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Dead! Heaven forefend! An you would give me time I wou'd ha told you ſhe's releaſed from yon fat fellow's tyranny; na more: out on him, filthy porpoiſe, aw the bowels in his belly, tho' he has got gude ſtore, dunna contain one grain of pity; troth, with his gude will ſhe might ha' ſtarv'd and periſh'd in the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p:
What is't you tell me? In the ſame breath you
bring my hopes to life and murder them again.—Starv'd in the ſtreets? I thought ſhe had an affluent fortune.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: In virtue, Sir, nought elſe, and that will not paſs current for a dinner. Zooks, an I myſall, by Heaven's gude providence, had na' ſtapt in upon the very nick of time, my life upon't ſhe had been loſt.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Come to my arms then, whoſoe'er thou art, and wonder not, for thou haſt ſav'd my daughter.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Daughter! Gadzooks, you make my heart jump to my laps for joy. Are you Miſs Aubrey's father?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I am her father.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: An if I'd found mine awn I cou'd na' been more happy. Wall, wall, I hope you'll merit your gude fortune; by my ſol you've got an angel of a child—But where have you been buried aw the while? for we believ'd you dead.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: You ſhall hear all my ſtory, but this is no fit place to tell it in: ſatisfy me firſt if my poor child is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Fear nought, ſhe's ſafe with Maiſter Mortimer; I laſt her but this moment.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Who is Mr. Mortimer?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Why, Maiſter Mortimer is one who does a thouſand noble acts without the credit of one; his tongue wounds and his heart makes whole; he muſt be known and not deſcrib'd: an' you will bait a-while in yonder tavern till I come from Bradgemore's, I'll accompany you to where your daughter is.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Agreed! I fear I've been miſtaken in this Bridgemore; three years ago I conſign'd to him a cargo of great value from Scanderoon; if he has robb'd me—but till I've ſeen my daughter, I'll ſuſpend enquiry. Step with me into yonder tavern, there we'll concert the means of bringing Bridgemore to an interview at Mr. Mortimer's. Come, my good benefactor, how fortunate was this meeting! I long to know to whom I owe this happineſs.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: And ſo, friend Napthali, Lord Abberville has had another tumble.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: A damn one.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I'm glad on't; this will wring his fine high hamper'd carcaſe to the quick.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: I'fait, he flings and winces ſo, I tremble to come near; he look as dark as India-ſtock upon a ſettling day.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the dice are little weapons, but they make deep wounds: what between thoſe that win and us that lend, he bleeds at both arms. Theſe are the bonds.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Take 'em: this is a memorandum of the premium on five touſand, and this the private contract for extraordinary intereſt. (Gives ſeveral papers.)

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Good, good, friend Napthali! The bonds give legal intereſt, and this doubles it. There, there, lye by and breed (puts them by;) but hark'e-me! Haſt brought the abſtract of the ſale of the Neptune's cargo?

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Aubrey's conſignment you mean.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: The ſame; but mum! That's between you and me: cloſe, cloſe, my little Napthali.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: A broker and betray his principal! That's not my vay; there is no ſenſes in that. Here I have make out your account; 'tis var coot bargain I have make conſidering diamond is a drug.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Why this tells well; it mounts; the raw ſilk was old gold; the carpetting and cottons not amiſs; and whuh! the rhubarb!

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, but vat is that?—Look at the coffee!

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Politics account for that; while news-papers bear price, coffee will hold its own. This rupture with the Ruſſians was in our favour here.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Ay, ay, a charming ſtroke: war is a var coot thing; and then the plague; a bleſſed circumſtance, tank Heaven; a bleſſed circumſtance, coot 7 per cent.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Let me ſee; altogether 'tis a thumping ſum: It netted forty thouſand: where's the conſcience, Napthali, that woudn't ſtrain a point for forty thouſand pounds?

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis all fair in the vay of trade; you cou'd not ſtrike a jury out of Jonathan's that woudn't acquit you. Well, Mr. Bridgemore, any thing more in my vay?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Nothing at preſent. Did you call at Lloyd's?

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p:
Odſo! well recollected! The Sea-horſe is arrived
from Scanderoon, ſhe that had ſuch high inſurances upon her.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: What d'ye hear? What paſſengers come in her? Is ſhe at Stangate Creek?

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: No, in the pool; ſhe brought clean bills of health from Leghorn.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Go, go; you have given me an ague-fit; the name of Scanderoon ſets all my teeth a chattering. (Exit Napth.) Well, would it had been poſſible to have kept my ſecret from that fellow—The Sea-horſe come at laſt!—Why be it ſo.—What ails me; what poſſeſſes me? If ſhe brings news of Aubrey's death, I'm a whole man; ay, and a warm one too.—How now; who's there?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Cawdie Macleod, a ragged Highlander, ſo pleaſe you, a wratched gaelly under ſavour of your raverence, na better.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I recollect you now for one of my Lord Abberville's retinue—Well, you have ſome enquiries to make about Miſs Aubrey.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ecod, you are cloſe upon the mark.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I gueſt as much; but ſhe is gone from hence, and you may follow.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Out on thee, ragamuffin; an I were not bound to ſecrecy, I'd gee thee ſic a pill ſhou'd lead that weam of thine the de'il a dance (aſide)

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: No, Maſter Colin, your Scotch policy will ſtand you in no ſtead this turn.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Then I'll forſwear my country—Well, you wull na' have my meſſage then, I mun gang bock to Maiſter Mortimer, and tell the Turkiſh trader you'll na' ſee him.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Hold, hold, what trader do you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Of one that's com'd a paſſanger from Scanderoon, aboard the what d'ye call the veſſel—the Sea-horſe I take it.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: What, who? It is not Aubrey.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Gude faith, I wou'd it was—the mon is dead.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Which man is dead; the paſſenger or Aubrey?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p:
Hoot! can't you think 'tis Aubrey?—By your
leave, truth, awhile; you will na' take it much to heart, an I make uſe of falſhood, to detect itſall (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I'll go to Mr. Mortimer's; I'll go with all my heart. Give me your hand; I aſk your pardon heartily, my honeſt friend—and ſo he is dead you ſay—you're ſure he is dead—pray, what diſtemper did he die of?

sp.speaker: Colin
sp.p: When a mon's in his grave, what matters whuch diſtemper laid him there?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: That's true, that's true enough. Pray you ſit down; I'll juſt run up and tell my wife and daughter—Zooks! ſuppoſe I brought them with me; will they meet a welcome think you?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ay, ſic a one as you don't look for, take my word.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I'm a new man; I walk upon the air.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ecod, the project takes; I drew for the cock bird, and have taken the whole covey.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Odds my life, Mr. Bridgemore, I forgot—Who's there?—that devil Scotchman.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Hold, hold, friend Napthali; you and I munna part. you muſt keep pace wi' me to Maiſter Mortimer's.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: To Mr. Mortimer's? Impoſſible: why I muſt be at Bank, Sir, I muſt be at Jonathan's: I've forty bargains to ſettle. I ſhall have half the Coffee-Houſe on my back. Wou'd you make me a lame duck?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Duck, or no duck, ecod, Sir, you muſt travel.

Heyday! I never ſaw the like before; I can't think what oſſeſſes my father; he's intoxicated; quite beſide himſelf with this confirmation of Mr. Aubrey's death; for my part, I derive no particular gratification from it; ſo that Auguſta had but one lover leſs, I care not if ſhe had forty fathers living: Tyrrel's the man of her heart, and in truth he is an object worthy any woman's preference; if I cou'd draw him from her 'twou'd be full retaliation for Lord Abberville—I'll go to Mortimer's; 'tis an untoward viſit; but I'll go there.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Come, buſtle, daughter, buſtle; get your cloak on, the coach will be here immediately: but where's my Scotchman? I forgot to aſk the ſtranger's name.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Where have you hid yourſelf, my dear? Come, are you ready? Your father's frantic with impatience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I follow you—Now, Aubrey, 'tis my turn.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Never tell me, you've acted like a giddy hot young man; put a few hear-ſay circumſtances together, ſhook 'em in an empty noddle, and ſo produced a compound of nonſenſe and ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I plainly ſee I've judg'd too haſtily.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Judg'd! pooh, I wou'd not give a ruſh for ſuch a judge: a magpye in a cage, that chatters out whore to every woman that goes by, will be as often right as you, and judge as wiſely: never talk to me of judging others, till you've condemn'd yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I do condemn myſelf; and if Miſs Aubrey does not ſign my pardon, I am diſpoſed not only to condemn, but execute.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Away then, and throw yourſelf upon the mercy of the court; it is the fate of bunglers to be aſking pardon.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Bleſs you, gude Maiſter Mortimer, I hanna ſlept in your commiſſion: yon fat fellow upon Fiſh-Street Hill is on his march with bag and baggage.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What mean you? Does he bring his wife with him?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Troth does he, and his daughter too; the plot is thick'ning you mun know apace, and yon ſame buzzard canna ſpy it out.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What plot is thick'ning?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Zooks, mon, you ſhall behold as pretty a diſcovery, come the time, as ever your eyes look'd upon; but aw things in their courſe; I mun gang home the whilſt, but I'll be quickly bock again, d'ye ſee.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do ſo, my friend; and hark'e, tell your Lord I beg half an hour's converſation with him, when and where he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I ſhall do that; but you mun know, while I was on my way, I croſs'd upon a Gentleman of no vulgar preſence, and conſidering he has ſojourned for a pretty many years with none but ſuch as we denominate barbarians, as courteous in his manners as your heart cou'd wiſh.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Why that accounts for it. Well, what of him?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: With your leave, Maiſter Mortimer, he'll tell you his own errand: troth, he wull'd me introduce him to you: he's without.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Admit him.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Gude faith, he has done that for himſall; he's not habituated to our ceremonies. Maiſter Mortimer, I pray Heaven take you to its holy keeping till I ſee you again.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Sir, your moſt humble ſervant. Can you forgive the intruſion of a ſtranger?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: A ſtranger, Sir, is welcome: I cannot always ſay as much to an acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I plainly ſee your experience of mankind by the value you put upon them.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: True, Sir; I've viſited the world from arctic to ecliptic, as a ſurgeon does a hoſpital, and find all men ſick of ſome diſtemper: the impertinent part of mankind are ſo buſy, the buſy ſo impertinent, and both ſo incurably addicted to lying, cheating and betraying, that their caſe is deſperate: no corroſive can eat deep enough to bottom the corruption.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Well, Sir, with ſuch good ſtore of mental proviſion about you, you may ſtand out a ſiege againſt ſociety; your books are companions you never can be tir'd of.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Why truly their company is more tolerable, than that of their authors wou'd be; I can bear them on my ſhelves, tho' I ſhou'd be ſorry to ſee the impertinent puppies, who wrote them: however, Sir, I can quarrel with my books too, when they offend my virtue or my reaſon.—But I'm taking up your time; the honeſt Scotchman, who announc'd you, told me you had ſomething of importance to communicate to me.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I have: I'm told I am your debtor, and I came with a deſign to pay you down ſuch thanks as your benevolence well merits; but I perceive already you are one, whom great profeſſions wou'd annoy, whoſe principle is virtue, and whoſe retribution riſes from within.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, no more of this; if you have any thing to requeſt, propoſe it: I'd rather much be told what I may do for you, than reminded of what I may have done.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I readily believe you, and according to your humour will addreſs you: I own you may confer a benefit upon me; 'tis in your power, Mr. Mortimer, to make me happieſt of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Give me your hand; why now you ſpeak good ſenſe; I like this well: let us do good, Sir, and not talk about it: ſhow me but how I may give happineſs to you, with innocence to myſelf, and I ſhall be the perſon under obligation.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: This then it is; you have a young perſon under your protection, a Lady of the name of Aubrey—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I have.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Reſign her to my care.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Put her into my hands: I am rich, Sir, I can ſupport her.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You're inſolent, or groſsly ignorant, to think I wou'd betray a truſt, a ſacred truſt: ſhe is a ward of virtue; 'tis from want, 'tis from oppreſſion I protect Miſs Aubrey—who are you, that think to make a traitor of me?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Your zeal does honour to you; yet if you perſiſt in it, and ſpite of my proteſt hold out, your conſtancy will be no virtue; it muſt take another name.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What other name, and why? Throw off your myſtery, and tell me why.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Becauſe—

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Ay, let us hear your cauſe.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Becauſe I am her father.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Do I live?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Yes, in my heart, while I have life or memory; that dear injur'd girl, whom you ſo honourably protect, is my daughter. The overflowings of a father's heart bleſs and reward you! You whom I know not, and that poor Highlander, out of his ſmall pittance, have under Providence prerſerv'd my child; whilſt Bridgemore, whom I rais'd from penury, and truſted with the earnings of my travel, has abandoned and defrauded her.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: O mother Nature, thou'lt compel me to forſwear thee.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Ah, Sir, you feel the villainy of man in every vein; I am more practiſed, and behold it only with a ſigh: Colin and I have laid a little plot to draw this Bridgemore hither; he believes me dead, and thinks he is to meet a perſon at your houſe, who can relate particulars of my death, in which caſe it is clear he means to ſink a capital conſignment I ſent him about three years ſince, and turn my daughter on the world.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, let him come; next to the ſatisfaction I receive in the proſperity of an honeſt man, I am beſt pleaſed with the confuſion of a raſcal.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Dear uncle, on my knees—what am I doing?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You thought I was alone.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: And what had you to tell me in ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I had a petition to prefer, on which my happineſs in life depends.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I beg I may retire: I interrupt you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: By no means: I deſire you will not ſtir; let him make his requeſt; if it is not fit for you to hear, it is not fit for me to grant. Speak out: nay, never heſitate.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: What can I aſk of you but to confirm my hopes, and make Miſs Aubrey mine?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
Was ever the like heard? Pray whence do you
derive pretenſions to Miſs Aubrey? Tell me in preſence of this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Not from my own deſervings I confeſs; yet if an ardent, firm, diſintereſted paſſion, ſanctified withal by her conſent, can recommend me, I am not without ſome title.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Look you there now: this fellow you ſhall know, Sir, is my nephew; my ſiſter's ſon; a child of fortune.—Hark'e, with what face do you talk of love, who are not worth a groat?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: You have allow'd me, Sir, to talk of love; openly, beneath your eye I have ſolicited Miſs Aubrey's conſent and gain'd it; as for my poverty, in that I glory, for therein I reſemble her whom I adore; and I ſhou'd hope, tho' fortune has not favour'd us, we have not loſt our title to the rights of nature.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Pooh! the rights of nature! While you enjoy it's rights, how will you both provide againſt its wants?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Your bounty hitherto has let me feel no wants; and ſhou'd it be your pleaſure to withdraw it, thanks to Providence, the world is not ſo ſcantily provided but it can give to honeſt induſtry a daily dinner.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Fine words! But I'll appeal to this good Gentleman; let him decide betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p:
In truth, young gentleman, your uncle has good reaſon on his ſide; and was I he, I never wou'd conſent to your alliance
• ith Miſs Aubrey, till ſhe brought a fortune large enough to keep you both.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Theſe are your maxims I've no doubt; they only prove to me that you love money more than beauty, generoſity or honour.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: But is your Lady in poſſeſſion of all theſe? Let me be made acquainted with her, and perhaps I may come over to your ſentiments.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Ay, Frank, go, fetch your girl, and let my friend here ſee her; I'm in earneſt. Upon my honour, nephew, till you've gain'd this Gentleman's conſent, you never can have mine; ſo go your ways and let us ſee if you have intereſt enough to bring her hither.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Oh! if my fate depends upon her looks, they muſt be iron hearts that can withſtand 'em.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p:
The manly and diſintereſted paſſion of this youth, while it poſſeſſes me ſtrongly in his favour, gives an aſſurance
of a virtuous conduct in my child; indeed, Sir, I am greatly taken with your nephew.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, the boy as yet has never made me bluſh; and if he holds his courſe, he may take one half of my fortune now, and t'other at my death—But, ſee, Sir, here your daughter comes.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: You are obeyed: you ſee the Lady, and you've nothing now to wonder at, but my preſumption.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: To wonder at! I do behold a wonder! 'Tis her mother's image! Gracious Providence, this is too much!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You will alarm her; your diſorder is too viſible.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I cannot ſpeak to her; I pray you let me hear her voice.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Why am I ſent for? is your uncle angry? how have I offended?—

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh, ſhe ſpeaks; 'tis ſhe herſelf, it is my long-loſt wife reſtor'd and rais'd again.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Pooh! what had I to do to meddle with theſe matters?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Why does that Gentleman regard me ſo attentively? His eyes oppreſs me; aſk him if he knows me?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Sir, if you know this Lady, if you've any tidings to communicate that touch her happineſs, oh! that I cou'd inſpire you with my feelings!

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I knew your father, and am a witneſs to the hard neceſſity, which tore him from an infant child, and held him eighteen tedious years in exile from his native land.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: What do I hear? You was my father's friend?—The prayer and interceſſion of an orphan draw Heaven's righteous benediction down upon you!

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Prepare yourſelf, be conſtant. I have news to tell you of your father.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I can't ſtand this; I wiſh I was any where elſe.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Courage, my dear Auguſta; my life upon it, there is happineſs in ſtore for thee.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Go on, go on.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: You are in an error, you are not an orphan; you have a father, whom, thro' toil and peril, thro' ſickneſs and thro' ſorrow, Heaven has graciouſly preſerv'd and bleſt at length his unremitting labours with abundance.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Did I not tell you this? Bear up.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Yes, virtuous Auguſta, all your ſufferings terminate this moment; you may now give way to love and happineſs; you have a father living who approves your paſſion, who will crown it with a liberal fortune, who now looks upon you, ſpeaks to you, embraces you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: There, there; I'm glad 'tis over. Joy befall you both!

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: See how her colour flies—She'll faint.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: What have I done? Dear innocent, look up.

sp.speaker: Aug.
Tyr.
sp.p: May all your days to come be nothing elſe! But look, ſhe changes again—Help me to lead her into the air.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: I believe a little air will not be much amiſs for any of us. Look at that girl; 'tis thus mortality encounters happineſs; 'tis thus the inhabitant of earth meets that of heaven, with tears, with faintings, with ſurprize: let others call this the weakneſs of our nature; to me it proves the unworthineſs; for had we merits to entitle us to happineſs, the means wou'd not be wanting to enjoy it.

div.stage: The Hall in LORD ABBERVILLE's Houſe.

sp.speaker: LORD ABBERVILLE.
sp.p: 'SDEATH, Sir, am I or you the maſter of this houſe? who made you judge what company is fit for me to keep? the gentlemen you excluded came by my ſpecial invitation and appointment.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Ay, gentlemen. Were they not ſuch?

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Under favour, I took 'em to be ſharpers; I know your Lordſhip always loſes, and I've notic'd that they always win.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Impertinence! I had debts of honour to adjuſt with every one of them.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Hang 'em, baſe vermin, pay them debts; pay your poor tradeſmen; thoſe are debts of honour. (half aſide.)

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: What is't you mutter? It was you too, I ſuppoſe, that drove away my Jew, that came with money to diſcharge thoſe debts.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: That's true enow, gude faith, I promiſed him a beating, and I kept my word.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Raſcal, thou'rt born to be my plague.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Raſcal! Your father never uſed that word.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: On your life, name not him: my heart is torn with vultures, and you feed them: ſhall I keep a ſervant in my houſe to drive away my gueſts, to curb my pleaſures, my purſuits, and be a ſpy upon my very thoughts; to ſet that cynic Mortimer upon me, and expoſe me in the moments of my weakneſs to that ſnarling humouriſt? I want no monitors to reproach me, my own thoughts can do that.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p:
Well, well! 'tis vary well! A raſcal! Let it paſs—Zooks, I'm the firſt Macleod that ever heard that word and
kept my dirk within my girdle—Let it paſs—I've ſeen the world, ſerv'd a ſpendthrift, heard myſelf called raſcal, and I'll now jog bock again acroſs the Tweed, and lay my bones amongſt my kindred in the Iſle of Skey; they're all that will be left of me by then I reach the place.

sp.speaker: La Jeun.
sp.p: Ah! dere he ſtand, le pauvre Colin in diſgrace! Ha! ha! ha! quelle ſpectacle! Ma foi, I muſt have one little vord wid him at parting—Monſieur le Financier, courage; I am inform my Lord have ſign your lettre de cachet: vat of dat? The air of Scotland will be for your healt; England is not a country for les beaux eſprits; de pure air of de Highlands will give you de grande appetit for de bonny-clabber.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Take your jeſt, Maſter Frenchman, at my countrymen an' welcome; the de'il a jeſt they made of you laſt war.

sp.speaker: La Jeu.
sp.p: Yes, you are all adroit enough at war, but none of you know how to be at peace.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: And theſe are all the money dealings you have had with Lord Abberville?

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: That is the amount of his debt; the bonds and contracts are in Bridgemore's hands.

sp.speaker: Mort.
Napth.
sp.p: Aubrey! Is your name Aubrey may I aſk?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Have you had any dealings with Mr. Bridgemore?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: To my coſt.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Did you conſign him merchandize from Scanderoon?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I am the perſon who was guilty of that folly.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Bridgemore I believe thought you was dead.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I take for granted he would gladly have me ſo—But do you know any thing of that conſignment?

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: Heh! Do I know of it? I had better make a friend of him; 'tis up with Bridgemore fait; there is no ſenſes in ſerving him any longer (aſide.) Why you ſhall know, Sir, I was Bridgemore's broker for your merchandize: here is the abſtract of the net proceeds (gives a paper to Aubrey, who peruſes it ſome time.)

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: That's lucky as I live; I ſee an honeſt man never can want weapons to defeat a knave—And pray, Sir, what might be your profit on this ſale; double commiſſion for a breach of truſt, that is the rule of the trade I think.

sp.speaker: Napth.
sp.p: I work as others; I do nothing below market-price.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: You're right, Sir; 'twou'd be ſtarving many an honeſt family, if you made roguery too cheap—But get you gone together to my library; I obſerve a perſon coming who will interrupt you.—Hark'e, Mr. Aubrey, have an eye to our Jew.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Truſt him to me: I'm pretty well accuſtom'd to their dealings.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Save you Sir, ſave you; is it true I pray you that a learned Gentleman, a traveller but juſt arrived, is now with you?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: There is a perſon under that deſcription in my houſe.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: May he be ſeen, good now? may he be talk'd with? what has he brought home? is he well ſtor'd with oriental curioſities?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, indifferent well; he has brought a conſiderable parcel of ſun-dried bricks from the ruins of antient Babylon; a heavy collection of ores from the mines of Siberia, and a pretty large cargo of common ſalt from the banks of the Caſpian.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ineſtimable!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, mere ballaſt.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Ballaſt indeed, and what diſcoveries does he draw from all theſe?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
Why he has diſcover'd that the bricks are not
fit for building; the mines not worth the working, and the ſalt not good for preſerving: in ſhort, Doctor, he has no taſte for theſe trifles; he has made the human heart his ſtudy; he loves his own ſpecies, and does not care if the whole race of butterflies was extinct.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Yes, putterflies—'tis in my mind, d'ye ſee, what you have ſaid about my putterflies: 'tis upon my memory; but no matter—your ſtudies Mr. Mortimer, and mine, are wide aſunder.—But go on—reform the world, you'll find it a tough taſk; I am content to take it as I find it.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: While the ſun ſhines, you'll carry a candle; how will that light them, who travel in the night? Away with ſuch philoſophers, here comes an honeſt man, and that's a character worth ten on't.— (COLIN enters.) So, Colin, what's the news with you? If I'm to augur from your countenance, ſomething goes wrong at your houſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, no mighty matter; only Laird Abberville has turn'd away a troubleſome fellow, who bore your honour grete gude will.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What is't you tell me? is my Lord determined upon ruin, that he puts away the only honeſt man belonging to him?

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: By this coot light, and that is well remember'd; look'e, I've got your wages: come, hold out your hand.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Axcuſe me, I'll ha' none on't.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: No wages? why 'tis all coot money; 'tis in full. What, man, think better on't; you'll want it when you get to Scotland, ten to one elſe.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Like enow, but by my ſol I'll touch na filler; he has geen a title to me, which I hanna merited, Heav'n knows, nor ever ſhall.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What title has he given you?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Saving your preſence it ha' pleas'd my Laird to ſay, I am a raſcall; but I'll na wear a raſcall's wages in a ſcottiſh pouch: de'il o' my ſoul, I'd ſooner eat my ſtroud for famine.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
I think thou woud'ſt, but wait a while with patience; this raſh young man's affairs preſs to a criſis; I have yet one effort more to make, which if it fails I ſha •…
take leave of him as well as you.

sp.speaker: Jar.
sp.p: Lord Abberville, Sir, deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: That's well. Colin, go you with honeſt Jarvis. Doctor, for once let us unite our ſtudies in this cauſe, come you with me; if my advice can reſcue your unhappy pupil from a courſe of guilty occupations, your philoſophy may furniſh harmleſs ones to fill their place: make haſte; make haſte, here come the Bridgemores.

div.stage: Servant enters, introducing BRIDGEMORE, his Wife and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Pleaſe to walk in here; my maſter will wait upon you immediately.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Nobody here!—Hark'e, friend, I expected to meet a ſtranger; a gentleman juſt landed from Scanderoon. Know you of ſuch a one?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He is now in the houſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And Mr. Tyrrel, Sir, is he at home?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: He is; they both will wait upon you preſently.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: That's well, that's well; as for old furly-boots we cou'd well ſpare his company; 'tis a ſtrange dogged fellow, and execrated by all mankind.

sp.speaker: Mrs Bridge.
sp.p: Thank Heaven, he is a man one ſeldom meets; I little thought of ever ſetting foot in his houſe: I hope the ſavage won't grow ceremonious and return the viſit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Unleſs he brings his nephew in his hand.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Ladies, you do me honour. Mr. Bridgemore, you come here upon a mechancholy errand—

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: True, Sir, but death you know is common to all men; I look'd to meet a gentleman here—this is all loſt time.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: True: therefore before he comes, let us fill it up with ſomething more material: I have a buſineſs to propoſe to you, which I conſider as my own. You muſt know, Sir, I've a nephew.—

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Mr. Tyrrel I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: The ſame.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Mind that, Lucy, he is opening his commiſſion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Law, Ma'am, you put me into ſuch a flutter.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: There is a certain Lady, Mr. Bridgemore, whom, on this occaſion, you muſt father.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: How tedious he is! Coudn't he as well have nam'd my daughter?—Well, Sir, what are your expectations from that Lady?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Nay, nothing but what you can readily ſupply: I know no good thing ſhe ſtands in want of, but a fortune.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, and who doubts but on a proper occaſion I ſhall give her one? Ay, and a tolerable fortune too, Mr. Mortimer, as times go.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: The fortune you was to have given my ward, Lord Abberville, will juſt ſuffice: I think the ſum was forty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Why you ſpeak out at once.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: 'That ever been my cuſtom; I abominate long ſleepy proceſſes; life don't allow of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: But I hear nothing on your part; Mr. Tyrrel, as I take it, is wholly dependant on your bounty—beſides, affairs, as I conceive, are yet ſcarce ripe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed, pappa, you're very much miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Why really, Mr. Mortimer, the parties ſhou'd at leaſt be ſuffer'd to conſult each other's inclinations.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: By all means; let 'em ſpeak for themſelves: 'tis their own cauſe, and they will plead it beſt: hark'e, come in, Sir, theſe are the parties.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: What ails you; have you trod upon a thorn?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhing aſſurance! Auguſta here?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Yes: Francis Tyrrel and Auguſta Aubrey. Do the names offend you? Look at the parties, are they not well match'd? Examine them, they'll tell you they're agreed. Who ſhall forbid their union?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Who cares about it? If Mr. Tyrrel and the Lady
are agreed, that's enough: I ſuppoſe it is not neceſſary for us to be preſent at the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, I pray you, where's the occaſion for us to be call'd in, becauſe your nephew chuſes to take up with an unworthy girl, that I once harbour'd upon charity?

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Hold your audacious tongue: let conſcience keep you ſilent.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Huſh, huſh! you frighten me; pray be compos'd; and let me own that no injuſtice, no ſeverity can wholly cancel what I owe to Mr. Bridgemore for his paſt protection, and that ſhare of education he allow'd me; but when he puts this to the account of charity, he takes a virtue foreign to his heart, and only aggravates the ſhame that's falling on him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Bridge.
sp.p: Is the man thunder-ſtruck; why don't you anſwer?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Charity keeps him ſilent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, let's begone: her words have daggers in 'em, and her looks are poiſon.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Before you go, Miſs Bridgemore, ſuffer me to aſk, when you related Lord Abberville's adventure to Mr. Tyrrel, why you ſuppreſs'd the evidence of your own maid, who conducted him into my chamber?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Miſs Aubrey, if it ever is your fate to have a rival, you will find an anſwer to that queſtion.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Hold, you and I, Sir, muſt not part. (To Bridgemore as he is going.)

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Well, Sir, your pleaſure?

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: I ſuffer for him; this is a ſcene I wiſh not to be preſent at.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Bridgemore, you that harbour'd my Auguſta upon charity, I ſhall leave my uncle to diſcharge my obligations to you on that ſcore, together with his own.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Well, Sir, we're now alone; and if it needs muſt be that one of us ſhall come to ſhame, 'tis well we are ſo. It is thought I am a hard unfeeling man; let it be ſo: you ſhall have juſtice notwithſtanding: innocence requires no more. You are accus'd; defend yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Accus'd of what; and who is my accuſer?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
A man; and you ſhall face him like a man. Who waits? (A Servant enters.) Deſire the ſtranger to
come hither (exit Servant.) Fear nothing; we're enough to try this queſtion; where the human heart is preſent, and the appeal is made to Heaven, no jury need be ſummoned. Here is a ſtranger has the confidence to ſay that your pretenſions to charity are falſe; nay, he arraigns your honeſty; a charge injurious to any man, but mortal to a trader, and levell'd at the vital root of his profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis the Turky merchant I ſuppoſe; let him come in; I know upon what ground I ſtand, and am afraid of no man living.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: We ſhall try that. Do you know this Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Aubrey!

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Thou wretch!

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: He lives!

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: To thy confuſion—Rais'd by the bounty of my family, is this your gratitude? When in the bitterneſs of my diſtreſs I put an infant daughter in your hands, the laſt weak ſcyon of a noble ſtock, was it to rob me you received her? To plunder and defraud an helpleſs orphan, as you thought her, and riſe upon the ruins of your benefactor's fortune?

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Oh! I am trepann'd! How ſhall I look my wife and daughter in the face (aſide.)

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Where have you lodg'd the money I depoſited with you at parting? I find my daughter deſtitute: what have you done with the remittances I ſent from time to time? But above all, where is the produce of the Neptune's cargo? Villain, look here, I have the proofs; this is the abſtract of the ſale; if you diſpute it, I am here provided with a witneſs, your Jew broker, ready at hand to atteſt it to your face.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: Expoſe me not; I will refund to the laſt farthing: I diſpute nothing; call him not in.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: There's no occaſion for witneſſes when a man pleads guilty.

div.stage: MISS AUBREY enters and throws herſelf on her knees to her Father.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Dear Sir, upon my knees I do beſeech you mitigate your ſeverity; it is my firſt petition; he's detected, let his conſcience add the reſt.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Riſe, my beloved child, it ſhall be ſo. There, Sir, your pardon be your puniſhment; it was my money only you attempted, my choiceſt treaſure you have left untouch'd: now go and profit by this meeting: I will not expoſe you: learn of your fraternity a more honourable practice; and let integrity for ever remain the inſeparable characteriſtic of an Engliſh merchant.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Stay; I've another point to ſettle with you; you're a creditor of Lord Abberville's: I find you've put Miſs Aubrey's money to extraordinary intereſt: Jarvis, ſhew this Gentleman into my library, you'll find a lawyer there will ſettle your accounts.

sp.speaker: Bridge.
sp.p: I think you've pretty well done that already—A fine viſit truly I have made on't; and a fine reception I ſhall meet at home.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: So! This uneaſy buſineſs paſt, let us now turn to happineſs: where is your Nephew?

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Conferring with Lord Abberville.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: Lord Abberville? You frighten me.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Fear nothing; you will find him a new man; a deep inciſion has let out the diſorder; and I hope a healthy regimen in time will heal the wound; in ſhort I can't be idle; and now Frank is off my hands, I've once more undertaken to ſet this ricketty babe of quality upon his legs—Oh, here he comes; why this is as it ſhould be; now you look like friends.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: May we be ever ſo! O, Mortimer, I bluſh to look upon that Lady; your reproofs I bore with ſome compoſure; but methinks was ſhe to chide me, I ſhould ſink with ſhame.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: You've nothing, my Lord Abberville, to apprehend from me: I ſhould be loth to give an interruption to your happineſs in the height of my own.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, Auguſta—In the hope that I was labouring for thy ſake, and in thy perſon that I ſhou'd reſtore the proſtrate fortunes of an ancient houſe, I have toiled on through eighteen years of weariſome adventure: crown'd with ſucceſs, I now at length return, and find my daughter all my fondeſt hope could repreſent; but paſt experience makes me provident; I would ſecure my treaſure; I would beſtow it now in faithful hands—What ſay you, Sir, will you accept the charge? (To Tyrrel.)

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: Yes, and will bear it ever in my ſight, watch over it with unremitting love, and guard it with my life.

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: What ſays my child, my dear Auguſta? But I read her looks—Bleſt be you both!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Amen, ſay I. Live an example to the age; and when I read the liſt of marriages, as I do that of burials, with a ſigh, let me have this to ſay, that there was one example of felicity.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
Mort.
sp.p: Why that's well ſaid; there ſpoke your father from within you: now begone; fly to the altars of your country lares; viſit that nurſe of contemplation, ſolitude; and while you range your groves, that ſhook at every rattle of the dice, aſk of your reaſon, why you was a gameſter.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: I've been a madman; I have loſt an humble faithful friend, whoſe ſervices wou'd be invaluable.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Why ay, your Highlander, your poor Macleod; our plan muſt ſtop without his help; I'm but a projector, he muſt execute—but there likewiſe I can ſerve you.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: O Mortimer, how much have I miſtaken thee!

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: Come, come, I have my faults; I'm an untoward fellow, and ſtand as much in need of a reform as any of you all.

div.stage: DOCTOR DRUID enters haſtily, followed by COLIN.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Tutor me truly—talk to me! Pray, Gentlemens, bear witneſs: is Maſter Colins here a proper teacher of the dialects, d'ye ſee, and pronunciations of the Engliſh tongue?

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Why not? Is there not Duncan Roſs of Aberdeen that lactures twice a week in oratory at the Seven Dials? and does not Sawney Ferguſon, a couſin of mine awn, adminiſter the Engliſh language in it's utmoſt elegance at Amſterdam?

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Bear witneſs, that is all I ſay, bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p: We do; there is not one amongſt us, Doctor, but can witneſs to ſome noble act of Colin's; and we wou'd not wound his harmleſs vanity, for any bribe that you can offer.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Colin, I've done you wrong; but I was not myſelf; be you no worſe a ſervant than you have been, and you ſhall find henceforward I will be a better maſter.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: I'm ſatisfied; an you'll neglect yourſall na more than I ſhall do, things will gang well enow.

sp.speaker: Tyr.
sp.p: I muſt apologize to Colin too; like my Lord Abberville, I was not myſelf when I rebuff'd you on the buſineſs of Miſs Aubrey's letter.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Say no more, Maiſter Tyrrel; 'tis not for a mon to reſent the pertneſs of a child, or the petulance of a lover.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.p: But what ſhall I ſay to him? where ſhall I find words to thank him as I ought?

sp.speaker: Aub.
sp.p: I father all your obligations; 'twas not you but me his bounty ſav'd.

sp.speaker: L. Abb.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, in point of obligation I ſtand firſt. By how much there is more diſgrace in doing than in ſuffering a violence, by ſo much I am more his debtor than you all.

sp.speaker: Colin.
sp.p: Ecod and that is true enow; Heaven ſends miſfortune, but the De'il ſends miſchief.

sp.speaker: Dr. Druid.
sp.p: Well, Maſter Colins, all is paſt and over; you have got your place again, and all is well. Coot now, let me admoniſh you for the future to be quiet and hear reaſon; moderate your choler and your paſſions and your partialities: it is not for a clown like you to prattle and diſpute with me; in fait you ſhou'd know better.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.p:
Come, come, 'tis you that ſhou'd know better; in this poor Higlander the force of prejudice has ſome plea, becauſe he is a clown; but you, a citizen that ſhou'd be of the world, whoſe heart philoſophy and travel might
have open'd, ſhou'd know better than to join the cry with thoſe, whoſe charity, like the limitation of a brief, ſtops ſhort at Berwick, and never circulates beyond the Tweed. By Heaven, I'd rather weed out one ſuch unmanly prejudice from the hearts of my countrymen, than add another Indies to their empire.
